title: man wins 50000 after bosses
story: Man wins £, after bosses unfairly fire him despite hearing he was suicidalThe health and safety coordinator had been off work for three months with severe depression and anxiety and his mental health dramatically plummeted after he was unfairly sackedDane Rowe had been off work for three months with severe depressionImage: Getty Images iStockphotoByGraeme Murray:,  Oct A health and safety worker has won £, after he warned bosses he was suicidal then tried to kill himself when they fired him. Dane Rowe, , aposspiralled into despairapos when he was unfairly sacked then attempted to commit suicide a day after his appeal was rejected. The health and safety coordinator had been off work for three months with severe depression and anxiety after his mental health dramatically plummeted. Mr Rowe, who has suffered mental health issues for  years, told bosses of his aposregular suicide contemplationapos and complied with their requests for regular sick notes while he was off. But, after he missed aposinformal wellness meetingsapos because he was so mentally unwell he couldnapost leave the house, he was unfairly sacked.  Mr Rowe, who worked for food producers David Wood Baking, has now been awarded £, compensation after suing them for disability discrimination and unfair dismissal. He had worked for the firm - which says it supplies aposluxury meals to the UKaposs top grocery retailersapos - in Newport, Wales, for two years when his mental health worsened in March  as the pandemic hit. Mr Rowe missed a dayaposs work and aposfabricated a bizarre explanationapos which apossnowballedapos and ended with him facing a disciplinary hearing before he finally admitted he lied and was given a final written warning. He was then off across April, May and June in  with severe depression and said he would be unable to attend a aposwellnessapos meeting at work. In messages across those months, he told managers: Iaposm really struggling mentally at the moment and spent most days isolated and alone in my flat as have been experiencing massive panic attacks when I try to go out. To be honest, Iaposm not well and Iaposm not coping. Iaposm struggling to find a reason to get out of bed each day and suicide is a regular contemplation. Iaposm in regular contact with my GP but all they can do is keep increasing my dosage of Mirtazapine which Iaposm not even sure is doing any good anyways. I just canapost get my head straight but Iaposm really trying.  He said his aposanxiety is through the roofapos and didnapost attend three of the meetings but continued to provide sick notes. He told bosses: Without sounding like a moan, the thought of going anywhereis still a little daunting. My intention was to come in today for meeting but I canapost leave the flat.  I know it sounds like a completely feeble excuse but Iaposve worked myself up into a state and now Iaposm frantic. I donapost know why as Iaposve been OK this morning but the last hour Iaposve been going out of my mind. Iaposve booked and cancelled three taxis now and feel like I just need to go back into bed and hide. Iaposm truly sorry to mess you all around I wish I could leave as planned. On July  he was dismissed without a disciplinary hearing for aposcontinuous absenceapos, perceived sick note failings, his aposinability to fulfil his contractual obligationsapos, and his failure to attend wellness meetings. He appealed and in early August received a letter informing it failed. As soon as a day later, Mr Rowe was hospitalised after a suicide attempt. Chair of the Cardf Employment Tribunal, Employment Judge Stephen Jenkins, said: We noted Mr Rowe attempted suicide in early August, a matter of days, possibly even only one day, after the receipt of the appeal outcome letter. It therefore appeared to us that the dismissal clearly had had an impact on him, and had exacerbated, potentially signicantly, his health and ability to work. We noted and accepted Mr Roweaposs evidence that, following his dismissal, he had felt in desperation, leading to thoughts of suicide, and that, when he knew that he was not going to go back to work having read the appeal letter, he aposspiralled into despairapos. Judge Jenkins ruled he was unfairly dismissed and discriminated on grounds of disability as David Wood Foods failed to make suitable adjustments. Judge Jenkins said: No investigation was undertaken in relation to the question of whether Mr Rowe had committed an act of misconduct. Had one been undertaken it would have been made clear he was suffering from ill health. David Wood Baking has been contacted for comment. The Samaritans is available  you need to talk. You can contact them for free by calling  , email jo@samaritans.org or head to the website to find your nearest branch. You matter. story: Meghan Markle and Prince Harry urge G leaders to get Covid jabs to poorer countriesThe Duke and Duchess of Sussex, Prince Harry and Meghan Markle, joined with World Health Organization and Save the Children in an appeal to G leaders meeting this weekendPrince Harry and Meghan Markle have demanded that the hold pharmaceutical companies have over access to vaccines must be broken Image: GC ImagesByMilo BoydReporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | comments Meghan Markle and Prince Harry have urged the worldaposs richest countries to send le-saving coronavirus vaccines to poorer nations. The Duke and Duchess of Sussex have joined the World Health Organization and Save the Children in an appeal to G leaders meeting this weekend.Theyaposve urged them to honour promises to get Covid- vaccines to low-income countries where just % of people have had a jab.In a two-page letter, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, Save the Children International CEO Inger Ashing and other leading voices in global health called for the world’s wealthiest countries to accelerate long-promised donations of vaccines.They coalition has demanded that the hold pharmaceutical companies have over access to vaccines must be broken.  “Among countries represented at the G, there are a handful with millions of surplus vaccines that are destined to be wasted once they expire,” the letter said. “Every discarded dose of a Covid- vaccine, when there are the mechanisms to donate them, should outrage us all. Each dose represents a real person—a mother, father, daughter, or son—who could have been protected.”  They pointed out that seven billon doses of Covid vaccines have been administered globally but Covax, the initiative designed to help fair achieve global access to vaccines, had only received .% of the promised . billion doses. Global targets have been set to vaccinate % of the population of every country by the end of  and % by the mid-. Decisions made at the G leaders’ summit in Rome this weekend could make or break those targets.  “By delivering already-pledged doses, helping countries manufacture their own vaccines, and prioritizing vaccines for nations in need, the G can help ensure the world delivers on these promises,” said the letter that was also signed by the Vaccine Alliance, UNAIDS, Clinton Foundation, Global Citizen and the Rockefeller Foundation. “We can’t simply hope for the pandemic to end on its own. As the virus progresses through unvaccinated populations, we risk new and more deadly strains sweeping the planet.”In the Spring Prince Harry urged people to “look beyond ourselves with empathy and compassion” during a speech at Vax Live.Harry, appearing without the Duchess of Sussex who was then expecting their second child, praised the world’s frontline medical workers at the concert. “Tonight is a celebration of each of you here, the vaccinated frontline workers in the audience and the millions of frontline heroes around the world,” he said. “You spent the last year battling courageously and selflessly to protect us all. children, including an autistic son, face being made homeless after her landlord sold their home. Beckie Searle, from Birmingham, is currently living in private rented accommodation but must leave by November .She cannot afford to continue private renting and has been told it could take months for her to find a council home, BirminghamLive reports.Birmingham City Council said there is a shortage of properties in the city and it is encouraging residents to look at the private market. Single mum Beckie, , has four children, Tyler aged , Jodie, aged , eight-year-old Kaine and five-year-old Leyla. Kaine is autistic and the strain on the family is having a particularly negative affect on him.  Jodie suffers from bronchitis and Leyla has mobility problems. Beckie has contacted Birmingham City Council for help but has been told she could face months to find a new home. The mum says private renting is too expensive and now faces splitting her young family up - a decision which she says will break her heart. The family have already packed up their belongings and are just counting the days until they have to leave their home. Beckie, who is currently claiming Universal Credit but is looking to go back to work as a support worker, said: The family will be split up as I will have to put them all up at dferent houses within our family. I need my autistic son settled.He is getting more aggressive than he usually is because of the situation. He doesnapost like to leave his bedroom because he doesnapost knowthat will be the last time he will see it. Two of my other children also have health problems. I have gone through the homeless department at the council but have told me that I have to wait six weeks before I get a bidding number to bid for a house. They have told me to private rent. Demand for housing in Birmingham is considerably greater than supply, this does regularly result in households who are homeless, being placed in emergency accommodation including BB’s, until a alternative option can be secured. title: pensioner devastated after caravan park
story: Pensioner devastated after caravan park forces him off site he used for  yearsDavid Capper said his dad was told he had just four weeks to purchase a brand new caravan at the Shanlieve Holiday Park in Kilkeel or his caravan would have to be removed.David Cappers father has been enjoying the caravan site for  yearsByConnor Lynch:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA pensioner’s family claims he was “forced off” the caravan site that his family have been using for more than  years as he could not afford the new caravan to park on it. David Capper said his -year-old father was told he had just four weeks to purchase a brand new caravan at the Shanlieve Holiday Park in Kilkeel or his caravan would have to be removed. The vehicle was deemed too old to be on the site, according to new rules imposed for holidaymakers or home owners parking up there. His father was devastated, he said, not being in a position to fork out the £, or more for a new caravan and facing losing the site he’d enjoyed for  years. David said he was “disgusted” someone who has been loyal to the site for so long would be given such an ultimatum. His father had spent a lot of money investing in the caravan and keeping it up to date, David said, but most importantly it holds a lot of sentimental value to him with memories of family holidays and spending time with his late we.I really cannot believe the way that my father has been treated by this caravan park after going there for  years and being such a loyal customer,” David told Belfast Live. He was given around four weeksapos notice that he would have to buy a new caravan, which would be £, or more, or he would have to have his caravan removed from the site altogether. “All they said was that the park would give him a £, discount off of the cost of a new one for his old one. For someone of my fatheraposs age to be asked to come up with that sort of money on short notice is ridiculous, although it would be the same no matter what age that you are. He has been left very upset by it all. That caravan is somewhere that our family grew up at, we would spend entire summers there and the memories and sentimental value that it has for my father is beyond measure. It was somewhere he had memories of our mother and now all of those are gone.  David said that there were dozens of owners at the holiday park who had been told the same thing as his father. He believed it was a problem affecting owners across Northern Ireland. It is not just Shanlieve that is doing this to owners, it is happening across Northern Ireland and it is ruining peopleaposs lives who have invested thousands into these caravans,” he said. Earlier this year, a group of  fuming caravan owners at Kingfisher Caravan Park on the Lincolnshire Coast announced they were taking East Lindsey District Council to court over the decision to boot out any caravans that were more than  years old. The group claims the council informed residents on the Ingoldmells site in October  of a change in the contract that meant caravans  years or older could not be there, YorkshireLive reports. After the deadline was initially pushed back for vans to be removed from the site, mainly due to the coronavirus-gtcoronavirus pandemic, the group now say they have until the end of the year to move them. However, after failed attempts at mediation the caravan owners say that they have no choice but to take the council to court over the decision. David said that due to the pandemic and more people wanting to staycation a lot of holiday park owners have become greedy and are pushing people out so that others will buy new expensive ones. “But in a year or two when people are going back to holidays abroad they will struggle because the previous loyal owners will want nothing to do with them. Something needs to be done soon to ensure that caravan owners have more rights because at the moment their circumstances seem to be able to change at the whim of a site owner. Milne Holiday Parks, who run Shanlieve Holiday Park, have been contacted for comment but not responded at the time of publication. story: Queens schedule would make most shudder - time to rest and for the heirs to step upThe Queen’s relentless schedule of late would let anyone half or even a third of her age shudder - now more than ever, it is time for her heirs and the rest of the family to step upHer schedule would make most shudder Image: POOL AFP via Getty ImagesopinionByRussell MyersRoyal editor:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsFor the Queen to pull out of such an important event commemorating our heroic war dead will have been the most awful wrench. There are very few dates cemented in Her Majestyaposs calendar and Remembrance Sunday, and indeed the weekend of commemorations surrounding it, is top of the pile. It is of some comfort that we are told the Queen has the firm intention of leading the nation at the Cenotaph on November , but after recent days of announcements of cancelled events it is now surely in the balance. The Queen’s relentless schedule of late would let anyone half or even a third of her age shudder.Do you agree  Have your say in the comment section Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm.Click here to sign up.Travelling , miles, across three countries, dozens of virtual and private meetings on top of a whole host of programming ahead of her Platinum Jubilee next year. Just how long that is enforced, which is seemingly the case for now as doctors continue to instruct her to clear her diary to get back to full health, no one knows. Now more than ever, it is time for her heirs and the rest of the family to step up and take the reins, while the Queen for once puts herself first above all . title: spooky sea ghosts look like
story: Spooky ghosts that look like humans emerge from sea - leaving locals terriedLocals have been aware of the phenomenon for some time and been mildly disturbed by them, but a new picture of the marine ghouls have brought them to a larger audienceThe strange sea ghosts pictured off Anglesey which have left people spooked Image: Craig FaircloughByAndrew ForgraveGraeme Murray:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsaposSea ghostsapos which look like humans and only occasionally emerge from the water have left beachgoers terried. Like ghostly apparitions, rising from the deep, they appear only occasionally to spook passers-by on Anglesey’s northern coast. For much of the time the cluster of figures remain submerged beneath the Irish Sea, only to reappear like maritime Chewbaccas or the Crew of the Flying Dutchman. Now that Halloween is approaching, the human-like shapes at Newry Beach, Holyhead, have gained wider fascination on social media. Locals have been aware of the phenomenon for some time and been mildly disturbed by them but a new picture of the marine ghouls have brought them to a larger audience. One person told NorthWales Live they do a double-take every time they walk past the eerie group.Another said: “I wouldn’t like to see them on a dark evening, very spooky.” A third added: “Actually that’s quite scary.... especiallyseen in the moonlight.” The photo was taken by Craig Fairclough of Chester, a regular visitor to the area in his touring caravan.He told North Wales Live : “I was walking the dog along Newry Beach when I saw what looked like human bodies emerging from the water,” he said.“I thought it would make a good photo, so I grabbed my mobile phone.“It was a spur of the moment thing. After the picture was posted on Facebook, it was shared widely with people saying how unique and atmospheric it looked.”The aposghoulsapos are in fact a seaweed-covered cluster of old wooden pilings from Holyhead’s former leboat ramp.Nature has fashioned them into human shapes that now stand testimony to the bravery of leboat crews who have operated out of Holyhead since . Over the centuries the rocky coastline and strong currents have caught out many a ship in the treacherous shipping lanes leading from Liverpool and Dublin.In the  years after the station was taken over by the RNLI in , the station lost seven leboat crew members as they battled to reach floundering vessels in the Irish Sea.The old leboat ramp now lies next to Holyhead Maritime Museum, which moved into the former leboat house – the oldest surviving one in Wales – in . Craig’s photo of the museum’s ghostly neighbours have intrigued fans of MR James, the medievalist scholar best remembered for his ghost stories. On a fans forum, one said it proved that Wales was a place where it was easy to get spooked. “It is a beautul country, but you can feel a dark sadness in these wild places,” he wrote. “It is a unique sensation here, I feel.” Comment MORE ON Ghosts" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: student left needing walking stick
story: Student needed walking stick after being spiked - but GP accused her of drug useA diabetic fine art student says she felt let down by paramedics, doctors and her students union over how they handled it, and still feels "vulnerable" during nights out five years laterLancaster University graduate Polly Sutherland was  when she was spiked five years ago, but says she still feels vulnerable going out now Image: PAByKate Buck:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA fine art student who needed to use a walking stick after being spiked on a night out has said she feels let down with how paramedics, doctors and her studentaposs union handled the incident. Lancaster University graduate Polly Sutherland was  when she was spiked five years ago, but says she still feels vulnerable going out all these years later. Miss Sutherland, from Stone in Staffordshire, had been on a night out at the universityaposs The Sugarhouse, run by the studentsapos union, in December  when friends noticed her behaving strangely. The graduate, who also has type  diabetes, said being drugged left her needing to use a walking stick for around a month because it damaged her blood sugar levels - something which can be fatal for people with the condition.  It took away the use of her drawing hand for weeks. Recalling the night, Miss Sutherland, now , said: I donapost remember anything suspicious happening, or noticing anything happening. It was just, later in the night, friends with me noticed that my personality changed - I seemed very dferent... erratic. So they took me home, I went to bed, but when I woke up in the morning I had a lot of bodily weakness and twitches in my arms, legs, all over really. She went on: When I went tothey werenapost very helpful. I remember feeling really disappointed, because I went to them saying aposFrom whataposs going on, I think Iaposve been spikedapos.  They almost raised their eyebrows, almost accusing me of taking drugs, and I was trying to get out of it somehow or making excuses. I felt very let down by the doctors at that point. Miss Sutherland had to apply for deadline extensions in the final year of her art degree because she could not paint or draw following the incident. She said she reported the incident to Lancaster University Studentsapos Union , but received little response. Asked how the incident made her feel, she said: Very... I donapost want to use the word violated, because maybe thataposs too strong. But itaposs scary to think what could have happened. Iaposm lucky that I had a lot of friends around me that took me home when they noticed something wasnapost right, so Iaposm very thankful for that, because I donapost know what purpose that person went out with.  It made me feel very vulnerable. Even now, when I go on nights out, Iaposm very cautious of it now, and itaposs in the back of my mind all the time. The graduate, who is now in her second year of a politics degree at Keele University, said she has joined the Girls Night In movement, which sees students boycotting clubs following reports of drink spiking incidents. But she said: The thing that bothers me is that, with the boycotting, the onus is on girls, again, to stay in. I think the fact that we are the ones that have to stay in because this is happening is putting it on us, itaposs our responsibility to make sure we donapost get spiked, instead of telling people not to spike people. Miss Sutherland said clubs should use CCTV and scan ID cards on entry, instead of just checking them by eye, so that they have a record of who attended each night. In a statement, Lancaster University said: We pride ourselves on Lancaster being a safe place to study and are distressed to hear about any of our students being assaulted in this way. The Sugarhouse is owned and managed by Lancaster University Studentsapos Union, and we cannot comment on inidual incidents. However,any of our students have safety concerns in relation to spiking, or any other kind of assaults, then we would strongly encourage them to report them to the university and we have created a range of ways to enable our students to do so. We would also encourage students to report any such incidents to the police. title: woman blew kisses after glassing
story: Woman blew kisses after glassing man while off her face on cocaine and boozeKatie Murphy, , "swilled" a drink at the stranger, Joseph Walker, and smashed the glass in his face during the sickening attack at Masquerade bar in LiverpoolKate Murphy blew kisses at a man she glassed on a night out Image: Liverpool EchoByAlan Weston:,  Oct | commentsA woman glassed a stranger and then blew kisses at him while off her face on cocaine and booze, a court heard. Katie Murphy, , attacked the man, Joseph Walker, as he was out for drinks with friends at the busy Masquerade bar in Liverpool.The glass narrowly missed Mr Walkeraposs right eye but he was left with signicant injuries which will leave him permanently scarred, the Liverpool Echo reported.Murphy of Stonyfield, Netherton, previously admitted she was off her face after a cocaine and alcohol binge which started the night before the attack on the evening of October  last year. She appeared at Liverpool Crown Court for sentencing on Friday after pleading guilty to causing grievous bodily harm without intent.  CCTV showed Mr Walker chatting and drinking with friends at the bar in the moments leading up to the sickening attack. Suddenly, while Mr Walker is looking down at his phone, he is approached by Murphy, who swilled a drink at him and smashed the glass in his face. She then blew two kisses at the victim before walking outside. Chris Hopkins, prosecuting, said: Mr Walker described a hand appearing with a glass which was thrust into his face. The glass broke with the impact. He bled profusely and was left with a jagged wound. He was taken to hospital and needed four internal stitches and  external stitches above his right eye. In his victim statement, Mr Walker said he now has a visible scar to his forehead, and he had become conscious of the way he looked. He added: I had a bubbly, happy nature before this happened, but I am now more nervous around people. I still donapost know why it was me she did it to. Maybe it was mistaken identity, maybe she just didnapost like the look of me. The injury was very close to my eye and it could have been a lot worse. Mr Walker bravely said he had forgiven his attacker. Mike Hagerty, defending, said Murphy accepted the victim of her attack was wholly innocent. He added: The defendant has a signicant mental health problem, including a diagnosis of paranoid schizophrenia, which is exacerbated by the use of drugs and alcohol. She has expressed regret and is remorseful. Judge Recorder Richard Leiper QC sentenced Murphy to  weeks in prison, suspended for  months. She was ordered to undergo a mental health and a drug rehabilitation programme, along with  hours of unpaid work. story: Woman who caught man taking naked photo of her says its unfair he only got cautionChloe James, from Fleet, was getting changed in a tanning salon cubicle when she saw a phone and a hand above her, taking a photoChloe James was getting changed in a tanning salon cubicle when she saw a phone and a hand above her Image: Mollie EmertonByEmma PengellyAlice Peacock:,  Oct A woman who had a man reach over a cubicle wall and take a photo of her when she was naked has spoken out about the lasting impact the incident has had on her. Chloe James, from Fleet, was getting changed in a tanning salon cubicle when she saw a phone and a hand above her. The perpetrator, a -year-old man from Aldershot, was arrested but later released with a conditional caution. Chloe said it feels unfair he can carry on with le as normal while she continues to feel the effects. Chloe has waived her right to anonymity, wanting to tell her story to raise awareness and change peopleaposs attitudes towards voyeurism. The -year-old said she sometimes has flashbacks of the incident, the memory of which “sends shudders” through her.“Itaposs not a nice feeling at all,” she toldSurrey Live.I thought I would get over it, but it happened in August. It still upsets me, itaposs an invasion of my privacy completely. Iaposm never going to get that back.A conviction of voyeurism, as defined underSection of the Sexual Offences Act , carries a maximum prison sentence of two years.It was August  when Chloe arrived at Tantastic in North Lane, Aldershot, for her appointment. She recalled: I walked in and the guy was talking to the owner. He kind of looked at me and we exchanged an aposare you alrightapos kind of look you do to someone you donapost know. He saw me walk into the cubicle, and then walked into the one next to me. I was just waiting for the bed to heat up, just standing there. Luckily, I just looked up and then I saw a phone. I just panicked. For him to get his phone over he would have had to have stood on a stool or sunbed or something. Theyaposre high walls. Chloe wasnapost wearing anything at the time and described her initial feeling of disbelief. I doubted myself, aposdid I just see that apos I went out and told the owner and had a complete panic attack and started crying, she said. She said the owner brought the man out and demanded to see his phone, but he refused.Chloe managed to get hold of his name and contacted him on Facebook. Over the app, in a message seen bySurreyLive,he then admitted wrongdoing.Chloe went to police the same day with this evidence. On October , the man was arrested and questioned, but the outcome was not what Chloe had hoped for. After admitting the offence to police, the man was given a conditional caution, ordered to pay £ in compensation to Chloe and attend a Victim Awareness Course by January , . Chloe tried to appeal the conditional caution decision on October , but police said it was not eligible for the Right to Review Scheme. A senior investigative officer did carry out a review, however, but they found the decision to be legal and proportionate, and the outcome was likely to be similar toit had been dealt with at court, a Hampshire Constabulary spokesperson said. Chloe said: Itaposs the first time he has done it, but I donapost think this is just a random thing you just do. Heaposs probably done it before. I went to police becauseit happened to me, this could be the start of something worse. Chloe added: Itaposs unfair I am still having to deal with it, and heaposs got away with it. Sexual assault [and other sexual offences] is happening so much more often, nothing is getting done. There needs to be a change. A Hampshire Constabulary spokesperson said: As a force, we take all allegations of sexual offences very seriously, and we have specialist officers who provide a compassionate and professional response to victims. Investigations into these offences are among the most complex that our officers carry out and cautioning offenders is just one example of formal action open to the police. When considering how best to deal with someone for any offence, we consider many factors including the circumstances of the case, the victimaposs welfare and whether they support a prosecution through the courts, whether there has been an admission of guilt, the offenderaposs situation, and the ages of those involved. Our officers are professional decision makers and on a daily basis make decisions about how to achieve the best outcome, when to give a community resolution, a conditional caution or pursue a charge with the Crown Prosecution Service . We do take the victimaposs wishes into account. Officers are making decisions about whether it is fair and proportionate to give someone a criminal record for their first offence, when theyaposve accepted responsibility, offered to remedy the crime, is considered unlikely to reoffend, and can be given a sanction that deters further offending. Cautions for the most serious offences are only used in exceptional circumstances and after advice is sought from the CPS. title: mum 30 sacked job school
story: Mum, , sacked from job as school volunteer after concerned parent outed her OnlyFans pageVictoria Triece, whose two children attend Sand Lake Elementary School, was told she could no longer take part in Orange County Public Schools’ ADDition volunteer programVictoria Triece talking to media during a press conference on Thursday Image: Zuma Press PA ImagesByMirror:,  Oct | commentsA mum who was barred from being a volunteer at her children’s school because of her racy OnlyFans account is vowing to sue the school district for  million. Victoria “Snooks” Triece, whose two children attend Sand Lake Elementary School, was told earlier this month she could no longer take part in Orange County Public Schools’ ADDition volunteer program. The notice came after an anonymous letter from a “concerned parent” outed her, her attorney said on Friday. Triece’s attorney, Mark NeJame, said the -year-old was “stripped” of the chance “to participate in her children’s lives with no legal or constitutional justication”. “What happened is somebody who took the posture of being a moralwrote a letter to the school and without notice she was unceremoniously dumped from being a volunteer,” Mr NeJame said.According toNew York Post reports , Triece had been volunteering in the district for five years, having passed a background check to do so.Now, she is no longer allowed to volunteer at the school, though she is allowed to chaperone field trips with her - and -year-old sons, NeJame said.  But NeJame said the latter point was only claried to Triece by OCPS officials prior to a press conference on Thursday, which he said suggested the school was “scrambling” to clean up their mess. Speaking to reporters, Triece said she had been on OnlyFans for more than two years, something she had never taken steps to hide.She also ran Twitter and Instagram pages which had attracted up to , followers and featured the heavily-tattooed mum in sultry poses.Speaking at the press conference, Triece said “nobody” has the right to judge what other people do for a living. “I feel judged, and so isolated,” she said. She went on to explain that she felt “humiliated” that someone felt the need to expose her online presence. “No one  should be concerned about what another parent does,” Triece said. “I just love spending time with my kids and I have a great relationship with other parents and students.” A school district spokeswoman had declined to comment on the matter, citing “potential, pending or ongoing litigation.” However, according to Orlando Sentinel reports, none of the guidelines for the volunteer programme explicitly stated what volunteers can or can’t do while on campus. Triece explained that her work le was separate to her being a mum, adding that she had the support of other parents at the school. “I think everybody’s just floored because they’re like, ‘We know you, we know who you are,” she said. story: Lava bomb spewed from La Palma volcano hurtles down hill as eruption continuesA "lava bomb" rolled at speed down the hillside from the Cumbre Vieja volcano in La Palma which is continuing to erupt after more than five weeks, destroying hundreds of buildingsThe lava bomb is seen hurtling down the hillside at speed Image: HARRI GEIGER via REUTERSByTim Hanlon:,  Oct | commentsA large molten lava bomb has been filmed hurtling down the hillside after being chucked out of the erupting volcano in the Canary Islands. The red hot piece of lava could be seen rolling at speed down the side of the volcano before coming to a stand still in the amazing footage from La Palma. Eruptions from the Cumbre Vieja volcano have continued to light up the sky on Friday night with no end in sight with so far around , buildings have been destroyed and , people evacuated. In the last few days the lava flows have appeared more fluid and the the track, labelled “number three” is currently the most worrying as it heads to the coastal villages of La Bombilla and Puerto Naos.  Maria Jose Blanco, director of Spain’s National Geographic Institute on the Canary Islands, said that the volcano is erupting “furiously” at the moment rather than showing signs of slowing down. The number three track has progressed around  metres in the last  hours said Ms Blanco and covering land that has not so far been affected by the lava flow. It is forcing some of those who have not so far been evacuated from villages in the area to have to leave their homes. Volcanologists have studied the lava bomb, the name given when the lava balls are larger than mm, and a video which has gone viral shows that the inside which is still red hot.  German scientist Harri Geiger’s clip of the rock has now had over , times. The volcano has now been erupting for more than five weeks and there continue to be regular earthquakes in La Palma. An earthquake on Tuesday was felt up to  miles away on other parts of the Canary Islands, a Spanish archipelago off northwest Africa. The rivers of lava cover over  hectares of mostly farmland, while one major flow is extending the island into the Atlantic as it cools. title: meta better facebook seven key
story: Will Meta be better than Facebook  Seven key questions answered, from safety to ownershipWhat does metaverse mean  Where did the term come from  Will it be safe  Will anyone run it  What does it all mean  For answers to all those questions and more - read onFacebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg announces the rebrand of Facebook as Meta Image: VIA REUTERSByEmily RetterSenior Feature Writer:,  Oct | commentsAn avatar of Mark Zuckerberg invites us to imagine stepping into a virtual reality version of our own home, only bigger, shinier, and with that view of a tropical ocean we have always dreamed of. Then he gets a call from apal, chooses an outfit for his avatar, and heads to a meeting with the avatars of hismates in a spaceship, where he receives a video call from hiswe showing him hisdog going wild in theirgarden.Confused  Most of us have probably got quite a bit of catching up to do, because according to the billionaire Facebook founder, this vision is quite possibly our future.The video posted by Zuckerberg yesterday was his attempt at introducing us to the metaverse - a theoretical future world of interlinking digital s, a fusion of virtual and augmented reality with, er, reality, which he and much of Silicon Valley believe is our brave next new frontier. On Thursday, in the wake of a damning wave of revelations and criticism aimed at the safety of his social media s, the tech tycoon announced he was changing the name of his company Facebook to Meta.What do you think about metaverse  Have your say in the comment sectionHe explained while his global social media juggernauts Facebook, Instagram and Whatsapp would continue to operate under the new umbrella name, its focus would now be on helping to shape and create the future metaverse.While critics pointed to distraction tactics, he explained: “Now we have a new north star to help bring the metaverse to le, and we have a new name that reflects the full breadth of what we do and the future that we want to help build. From now on, we’re going to be metaverse first, not Facebook first.” But what is it, and what might it mean for us all  What does metaverse mean  A fusion of meta, meaning ‘beyond,’ and ‘universe’, the word is being used to describe a future space where our real-le physical world and digital worlds increasingly blend. In this “immersive” world people would be represented by avatars - digital forms of themselves, be that close to le, or fun cartoon figures - or even holograms, and meet in virtual or augmented reality worlds to socialise, watch concerts, shop, learn, or work.  Virtual reality is a completely digital world, whereas augmented reality is where some elements of the digital world appear on top of the real world, like the Pokemon Go game.The vision is for a plethora of digital worlds, be they created by Meta, Google, Apple etc, to be interlinked so users could flit between them. It could change the internet completely.Where did the term come from  Not Zuckerberg. The word was first coined back in  in a sci-fi novel called the Snow Crash by American writer Neal Stephenson. It described a computer generated D virtual reality where people were present as avatars in a digital representation of the real world. Will the metaverse be safe  Zuckerberg’s social media s have come in for heavy criticism in recent weeks over safety. Key fears for a future metaverse are privacy and security. It would not only be ‘old-fashioned’ data like gender and age weaponised by trolls, advertisers, hackers, and even states, but potentially our body language, movement, moods, biometrics. Our opinions, information and community could be even more manipulated than now. Facebook announced million would go into building the metaverse “responsibly”, allocating that to a number of organisations and academic institutions.  Sir Nick Clegg said: “The way I look at it, in the past the speed at which new technologies emerged sometimes left policymakers and regulators playing catch up. “I really think that it doesn’t have to be the case this time round because we have years until the metaverse we envision is fully realised, this is the start of the journey not the end.” How will we access the metaverse, and can you already  The metaverse is already in its infancy, although far from being a joined-up universe.The computer game Fortnite is a good example. Now far more than a game, it is a virtual land where players can visit, meet and even watch events, including real-le fashion shows and concerts - Ariana Grande is the latest artist to perform there. You can also enter an early form through Zuckerberg’s Oculus VR headsets. The company has an app called Horizon Workrooms, which lets people wearing them go into virtual offices. Reportedly, Nick Clegg, the company’s VP of Global Affairs, holds his Monday meetings this way, round a virtual table. The company is reportedly now developing a better headset, codenamed Project Cambria, which has “improved social presence, colour passthrough, pancake optics, and a lot more”. What do those terms mean  Social presence means how real it feels to be alongside others. The new device hopes to allow avatars to keep eye contact, and have more developed facial expressions that even reflect each other. Passthrough means how real the world you are in seems to you - asyou weren’t wearing a headset at all. It is hoped it will be colour, whereas with Oculus it is black and white. Pancake optics are the lens, and aim to be lighter, with clearer focus. The company is also reportedly experimenting with AR glasses. How long will it take for a fully ing metaverse to be created  Zuckerberg believes a billion people will be using it in a decade’s time, and to help with that he wants his newly-named Meta to become a “metaverse business”, announcing plans to hire , people across the EU. Will anyone run the metaverse  Zuckerberg has said he will put tens of billions of dollars into it, but, like the internet, no one company will run the metaverse. However, anyone instrumental in helping to build it will have a lot of sway - andit becomes a key form of human interaction, that could be a lot of power. title: star return to league action with victory
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.RJD-sponsored Red Star travelled to Ballerup, East Kilbride on Saturday October  to play their first league game since February  and ed home with three points after an excellent overall performance.The visitors started the game on the front foot and could have been ahead after three minutes when Fraser Talbot#s long range effort came crashing back off the bar.Star didn#t have long to wait before they opened the scoring, however, as Stuart MacLean reacted quickest to a slip in the Duncanrig defence to put his side ahead four minutes later.Talbot again came close to his first Red Star goal but was denied by the crossbar for the second time after finding space to shoot in the box.The lead was doubled soon after when Aaron Moore linked up well with Stuart MacLean on the right channel and powered his shot through the hands of the Duncanrig keeper.Star had several chances to make the game safe in the opening half hour with Craig Aitken and Andy Weir providing the ammunition from the wide areas but the final touch was slightly lacking.Coll McCallum was next to rattle the bar as his long-range effort took a bizzare bounce over the keeper#s head but the woodwork was once again kind to the hosts.Duncanrig pulled themselves back into the game with a rare attack which saw Star switch off and concede a disappointing goal as the midfielder was able to burst through the Star spine unchallenged to leave Ally Lewis with no chance.This stung Star back into action and the two-goal cushion was restored before the break when an excellent counter-attack saw Talbot lay a perfectly weighted pass into the path of Aitken, who finished with great composure to give Star a - lead at half time.Star looked to put the game to bed as quickly as possible in the second half and did so as Aaron Moore grabbed his second of the afternoon following a slip from the Duncanrig keeper.MacLean was next to double his tally as he proved too sharp for the Duncanrig defence and finished well from a tight angle to make the score - with half an hour to go.This gave manager Weir the chance to ring the changes, with Ryan Caskie coming on to replace Aaron Moore and helping himself to two goals of his own from close range to make the final score -.The only sour note was an injury to goal-scoring substitute Caskie which will rule him out of Star#s next game.Star look to make it back-to-back wins on Saturday October , again on their travels to Port Glasgow OBU.

title: peebles-destruction-communal-garden-very-disturbing
story: THE destruction of a recreational area in the Borders has been ldquoshocking and very disturbing for residents, says a Tweeddale councillor.But Heather Anderson, of the SNP, says that there was no illegality in the developer removing the communal garden in Peebles as he owns the land.The developer had wanted to build two houses on the ground, but Scottish Borders Council rejected the plans as it had been earmarked for a play recreational area.The landowner appealed to the Scottish Government, but by the time an official visited, residents of Ballantyne Place had added slabs, shrubs and trees to the space.However, a bulldozer was used to remove the communityrsquos additions earlier this month, leaving everything in ldquoa big pile.:Borderers urged by council to prepare for lsquoheavy and persistentrsquo rainfallldquoBecause the owner owns that site, there was no illegality in him displacing the landscaping, said Ms Anderson, who confirmed that she had approached council officers to see what action could be taken.ldquoI also got officers to check whether the site was safe for the public, and they assured me that it was safe, but it was still a slightly shocking event that was captured on camera.The Tweeddale West representative added: ldquoWhat we now have to try and do is ensure that the residents of Ballantyne Place and that owner hopefully navigate a mutually agreeable solution to how to use that piece of land.The space had been used as an area for households to come together to enjoy barbecues.One resident, who does not want to be named, told the Peeblesshire News: ldquoWe set about clearing it from all the rubble and weeds. A good amount of people in the street got together and helped out. We got slabs, sand, shrubs and trees, which were donated by a local gardener. We thought wersquod make it presentable and nice.:A great shame: Public toilets to close after Peebles residents failed townldquoWe knew about the planning application, but none of us thought houses should be built on it. The key thing is, this is the only bit that is left for a recreational area. Wersquove hosted ious things on this space, including the kids doing a magic show and raising money for charity.The homeowner said that residents in Ballantyne Place ldquohad a fear that their communal garden would be ldquodestroyed.ldquoTheyrsquove uprooted trees and dumped them, said the resident. ldquoEverything has just been left in a big pile. Everyone is just gutted and upset ndash we had big plans for the space. It really brought us together, and the sad thing now is, therersquos nothing there now.The original development was granted planning permission on the basis that a play recreation area should be installed.:Background reports ordered into Borders man who admitted three assault chargesHowever, when the land was sold to the current developer, he lodged an application to build two houses on the ground.That was subsequently rejected by the council.The developerrsquos appeal was thrown out by the Scottish Government reporter who said the requirement for a play area should be protected, and this piece of land is the only place it could be located.The Peeblesshire Newscontacted the developer but had not received a response at the time of going to press.

title: spanish-activists-joined-borderers-21-mile-trek-kelso
story: ENVIRONMENTALISTS who are walking from Portsmouth towards Glasgow for the COP conference stopped in the Borders at the weekend.And they were joined by local activists.The group of ten Spanish activists are taking part in the Marcha A Glasgow to highlight the issue of climate change.On Sundaythe group, joined by two Borderers, walked  miles from Wooler to Kelso.:Fourteen flood warnings issued across Borders with further rainfall expectedldquoIt was absolutely terric, said Kate Prasher, a member of Extinction Rebellion Scottish Borders, who joined the walkers for  of their -mile trek, along with Kath McDonald.Kate, , told the Border that although the Spanish group may not spend the full two weeks of COP in Glasgow, their goal has been to highlight the climate crisis.She said: ldquoThey have made links with people across the country, from Portsmouth to here.ldquoThere is now a string of connections between people of all backgrounds.ldquoThese people have left their lives in Spain behind and they are literally walking for the sake of the climate.ldquoTo be part of that is a privilege.:John Lamont MP hits back at sewage vote misinformationOn Monday the Spanish group set off from Eccles to Lauder.Over the course of their ,km journey, the group has updated their followers with a series of blog posts about each of their stops.While in Kelso the group shared: ldquoA long and eventful day today saw us leave Wooler and up the Cheviot hills between the gorse and bracken, hauling ourselves up and down and then up again until the murmurs of discontent subsided when we reached the peak of Yeavering Bell which is  metres above sea level.ldquoHere the wind was vicious and almost blew us off our feet but we were rewarded with a panoramic view stretching from the North Sea across Northumberland to the Scottish Borders.ldquoOnce off the hills we picked up the B road which was almost as quiet as the mountains but much more conducive to completing the dayrsquos -mile walk before dusk.ldquoThe long, straight, quiet county road seemed to go on forever as we walked west toward the falling sun, finally turning northward to be greeted by local activists and a photographer from the local paper who led us into the beautul old town of Kelso where we drank whisky and listened to a bagpiper in the town square before heading to the local Friends Meeting House for dinner and folk music from local musicians.ldquoAs ever the food and hospitality was absolutely top notch, wherever we go we are treated like royalty.:Destruction of communal garden in Borders very disturbing, says councillorMs Prasher will join other activists from across Scotland in Glasgow on the weekend of November - where she will take part in a march and will help to display the Stitches for Survival banner ndash which a number of Borders knitters, crocheters and stitchers contributed to ndash on Glasgow Green.To follow the rest of the Marcha A Glasgow grouprsquos journey, visit: marcha-a-glasgow.net en home

title: darcy-graham-set-20th-cap-bt-murrayfield-saturday
story: FORMER Hawick player Darcy Graham has been selected for Scotlandrsquos opening match of the  Autumn Nations Series against Tonga at BT Murrayfield on Saturday  October ndash kick-off :pm.This will be the Edinburgh flyer Grahamrsquos th international appearance having earned his first cap coming off the bench against Wales in Cardf for the Doddie Weir Cup in November .He starts at full-back and is joined in the back three by Glasgow duo Kyle Steyn, who will add to his single cap won against France in the last match at BT Murrayfield played in front of crowds in March , and Rufus McLean who will make his first Scotland start.Joining McLean on Scotland debut will be clubmate Sione Tuipulotu who lines up with fellow Glasgow Warrior Sam Johnson as the centre partnership.Co-Captain and Lions scrum-half Ali Price teams up with Edinburghrsquos Blair Kinghorn at fly-half to form a brand new half-back pairing.In the pack fellow British  Irish Lions Zander Fagerson starts at tighthead prop with Hamish Watson at openside flanker, as they feature for Scotland for the first time since the South Africa tour this summer.Edinburgh Rugbyrsquos Jamie Ritchie, also named as Co-Captain, packs down on the blindside of the scrum which is anchored by Glasgow Warriorsrsquo Matt Fagerson at number eight.Youth and experience combine in the second row which sees Rob Harley earn his rd cap for Scotland and joined by Edinburgh lock Jamie Hodgson, who will win his first cap.Up front George Turner starts at hooker with Fagerson and with a debutant on the loose-head side in Edinburgh Rugbyrsquos Pierre Schoeman.Edinburgh Rugby provide forward replacements on debut in the form of lock Marshall Sykes and back-row Luke Crosbie.Glasgow Warriors half-back partners Jamie Dobie and Ross Thompson are the uncapped backs.Former Scotland Captain Stuart McInally is available off the bench alongside Glasgow props Jamie Bhatti and Oli Kebble in the front row, with backrow forward Nick Haining of Edinburgh completing the matchday squad.Scotland Head Coach Gregor Townsend said: ldquoAs a playing and coaching group we are looking forward to ing to international rugby over the coming four weeks in the Autumn Nations Series.ldquoThis week has been our first opportunity since the Six Nations to come together as a team, and our goal is to become a better team over the next month. Saturday will also be a huge occasion for a number of players in our squad who have the honour of playing for their country for the first time.ldquoTonga will be very dangerous opponents for us, as they pose a ferocious physical challenge in attack and defence. They performed very well on their last visit to Scotland and Irsquom sure they will be highly motivated to take the game to us once again.
