title: 100 years since historic split
story: VETERAN footballers from Northern Ireland and England turned the clocks back in Newcastle last Friday afternoon in a repeat of a historic clash between the sides a century earlier.The game mdash attended by Secretary of State Brandon Lewis mdash was organised by Tollymore United as part of its lsquoStormont and Soccer Splitsrsquo project supported by the Shared History Fund administered by the National Lottery Heritage Fund.The teams replayed a famous match that took place between Ireland and England on October , , at Windsor Park in Belfast, with the players wearing replica kits.The game a century ago was the first to take place after the Southern clubs split from the Irish Football Association to form the Football Association of Ireland.The historic fixture was repeated at Tollymore Unitedrsquos Bear Park ground at Donard Park with Tollymore club secretary, Andy Hall, revealing that players and officials were really surprised when told that Mr Lewis was attending Fridayrsquos match.ldquoI think itrsquos the first time a Secretary of State has been down to Newcastle, he continued. ldquoMr Lewis was very impressed with the incredible views of Slieve Donard and I would guess he is a big football fan as he was talking about great players like the late Martin Peters.The organisers of the event remained as authentic as possible, with the replica kits similar to the ones worn  years ago made in Belfast by Brennanrsquos Health and Beauty Unorms.ldquoAnd this was no mean feat as they only had pictures to go on, said Andy. ldquo Ireland played in blue at the time and not the more familiar green that they wear now.ldquoMr Lewis also said he thought the project was really unusual and he really liked the fact that the teams were playing in a replica kit.The Irish FA changed the international team name to Northern Ireland in  for FIFA competitions and in the early rsquos adopted the name for all other internationals.ldquoFriday was a terric sporting occasion that everybody really enjoyed. The replica kits were brilliant even though the shorts were a wee bit too long for my liking, said Tollymore club chairman Adrian Howard.ldquoOur guys really got into the spirit of things with the  moustaches and at one point I thought history was repeating itself with the teams locked at -. But it wasnrsquot to be with the English boys winning -.After such a wet and dismal start to last week, Donard Park was bathed in sunshine for the match and despite all the best laid plans, the England team was delayed on route from the airport.However, this gave Mr Lewis the opportunity to meet some volunteer coaches and officials from the Tollymore club. He chatted to coaches Simon Thornton and Dr Gavin Devlin about their involvement with the club and volunteering in general.Mr Lewis also met Seamus Heath and Mark Hughes, from the NI Veterans team who were involved in organising the fixture.The project is one of  funded through the Shared History Fund which supports groups to mark the Centenary, in a thoughtful, inclusive and engaging way.The Tollymore Club has been working on its project since October last year and was very pleased to hear that it had been awarded funding to deliver the project and to date the ious events have been extremely well received.ldquoI would like to thank everyone for taking part and making this part of our project such a success, in particular, the guests for attending and Rob Manley of the Anchor Bar for providing gts for the Secretary of State, council chairwoman Cathy Mason and Darren Rice from Heritage Lottery NI, said Adrian.The Tollymore club presented a number of gts to the Secretary of State including a framed print of Newcastle, circa , provided by Mr Ivor Anderson. He also received a replica  England top and The Friend at Hand Irish Whiskey presentation box.Gts of The Friend at Hand Irish Whiskey were also made to the council chairwoman and Mr Darren Rice.Also in attendance at the event was South Down MLA Jim Wells, a huge Northern Football fan and regular attender at the teamrsquos home fixtures.The latest football match starring the veterans is a testament to how far the teams have developed over the past few years.Formed almost  years ago after Tollymore United organised a long running five-a-side football programme, the NI Veterans encourage men that had stopped playing regular football to get back playing.The veterans believe that age should not be a barrier to playing football and that there are incalculable health benefits, both physical and mental, to keeping active.Players ages range from rsquos through to rsquos with teams at over rsquos, over rsquos, over rsquos and over rsquos age groups.Every year the NI Veterans take part in a home internationals tournament with their English, Scottish and Welsh counterparts and travel to venues across the UK, with the home internationals played in a dferent country each year.Players meet their own travel and accommodation costs with Tollymore United offering their pitch for home fixtures and the Anchor Bar providing visiting teams with food and refreshments.Veteranrsquos football is huge in England and Wales with organised leagues and dozens of teams. It is also becoming increasingly popular in Europe with the NI Veterans having played European opposition.Last Fridayrsquos football match was the third of four events that the Tollymore club is delivering as part of their project.The first part of the project was a talk on the events leading up to lsquoThe Partition of Irelandrsquo with leading historian Dr Cormac Moore and took place in July. It can be viewed at the following link https:player.vimeo video .The second talk on lsquoThe Irish Soccer Splitrsquo was also delivered by Dr Moore and told the story of why Southern clubs broke away from the Irish Football Association in  and can be viewed on https:vimeo event  embed eae.The final talk on lsquoThe Day to Day Consequences of Partitionrsquo with Dr Moore is scheduled for Thursday, November , and is available at https:vimeo event  ffdb.Dr Moore is currently a historian with Dublin City Council and helping to deliver their decade of commemorations programme..prettyPhoto

title: Ballynahinch seconds make light work of Carrick outfit in Junior Cup
story: BALLYNAHINCH seconds were almost at full strength for the visit of Carrickfergus on Saturday in the Junior Cup.Gareth Gill ed to a heavy duty back row with Andrew Foster and Keith Dickson while the front row of John Dickson, Kelvin Hamilton and Harry McCormick combined power and handling ability.In the backs, Conor Gibson filled in at nine with James McBriar pulling the strings at out-half and Ben McMullan adding pace at full-back in the absence of Adam Gowdy.Carrick had the wind advantage in the first half and the game was evenly matched with the away side full of energy in the opening exchanges.Inexperienced with Ballymacarn Park conditions, they perhaps didnrsquot use the wind as well as they could have and also missed a few very kickable penalties.This cost them as a Gareth Gill try on half-time after a multi-phase siege on the Carrick line added to Ben McMullanrsquos early score gave Ballynahinch a  point lead turning round with the conditions.Carrick had just a solitary penalty to show for their efforts and the Ballynahinch supporters knew that another score would effectively close out the contest.Replacement prop Nacho Caldera Crespo duly delivered with a typically strong carry over the line and a Paddy Browne penalty stretched the lead further as Carrick began to tire.Browne then converted Gillrsquos second as Ballynahinch pushed out to a - lead.To their credit, Carrickfergus continued to battle and scored probably the best try of the day through winger Simon White after an excellent line-break and wide pass from scrum-half Conor Cambridge.The home pack then turned the screw with three tries in the final  minutes to put a little gloss on the scoreline.Tries from Stuart Evans and Keith Dickson bookended a superb breakaway and finish from lock forward Matt Connolly who had just enough in the tank to make the line as the clubhouse crowd roared their approval.If they can continue to field this kind of powerhouse pack of forwards over the rest of the season the seconds will be a very dficult team to beat.A few strike runners are back from injury and unavailability in the back line and the coaching team will hope for another home tie when the tournament resumes in early December..prettyPhoto

title: Ballynoe secures new speed limit
story: A -YEAR campaign for a new speed limit in Ballynoe has come to a successful conclusion.New signs informing drivers that the new mph limit is now operating were erected recently to the delight of residents who have been campaigning to make the main road which runs through the heart of the village safer.Downpatrick area councillor Cadogan Enright, who has been lobbying for the new speed limit, said the journey to secure the mph limit had not been an easy one.He said that historically Ballynoe, had been ldquopassed over for any traffic calming measures as a result of old road regulations.Cllr Enright explained that several years ago, new traffic calming regulations were published which indicated that Ballynoe met new criteria for a speed limit and revealed that along with residents, he measured theof the village, counting the number of buildings which included a pub, GAA club, community centre and old shop.ldquoI was able to show that we clearly met the new criteria, the councillor continued. ldquoWe were finally put into the queue for assessment for traffic calming and followed this up with a petition signed by everyone in the village.ldquoThe Road Service had to carry out consultations with other agencies and hold a public consultation, with the proposal for the new mph limit submitted for the necessary legislation to be processed.Cllr Enright explained this involved the roads order being advertised in local newspapers with a further consultation period set aside for any comments, all of which took a long time.He added: ldquoWhile we were looking for mph signs, Roads Service consulted on mph signs. In my opinion this does not appear to be consistent with the regulations which clearly suggest mph was more appropriate, but it is still a positive result after many years of campaigning.ldquoRoad Service Officials confirmed to me last January that the mph limit would be introduced this year and we have all been tenterhooks waiting delivery day. It is great to see this project over the line at long last.Ballynoe resident, Billy McGrath, has appealed to parents whose children attended Legamaddy School to respect the new speed limits.He added: ldquoIt gets a bit frightening here sometimes in the morning so can everyone please slow down..prettyPhoto

title: Better paths plan on banks of Quoile
story: PLANS to signicantly enhance riverside walks along the banks of the Quoile in Downpatrick have taken a major step forward.Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Covid recovery working group has agreed to fund a new master plan which is being drawn up for the area, with representatives from a number of key organisations asked for their input on the way forward.The investment proposal is part of a part of a much-needed refurbishment project at a part of Downpatrick which is popular with local people and visitors to the areal, with plans to upgrade large sections of the Quoile River walk from the Belfast Road, along Janersquos Shore pathway to connect to the Quoile Pondage.The works will include the replacement of ageing boardwalks, fencing and gates with updated sigs provided. Similar to previous improvement schemes at the Quoile Pondage, the path will also be widened and the surface improved to make it much more accessible for families and those with disabilities.Cllrs Oonagh Hanlon and Cathy Mason have welcomed the Covid working grouprsquos decision to support the master plan which will upgrade existing pathways which have are becoming increasingly popular.Cllr Hanlon said the master plan also proposes the creation of new greenways and trails and is keen to hear from residents and visitors how they would like to see the area developed.ldquoThis will be vital in enhancing the tourist and heritage offerings we have locally and create better linkages to the town centre, she continued.ldquoThese plans complement the local councilrsquos ongoing plans to carry out repairs to the popular Lecale Way walking trails at Janersquos Shore and at Sheepland in Ardglass and other areas trails around the Lecale coastline.Cllr Mason said as a result of the impact of the pandemic and the restrictions introduced to curb the spread of the virus, many areas have experienced an increased use of outdoor open spaces.She continued: ldquoThis has been so important for the health and well-being of residents and visitors to our area. The Quoile in particular has been extremely busy with families and friends using the location for running, walking ,cycling or simply meeting up with each other. The need for good quality outdoor space has never been as important.lsquoIt is fantastic to see a commitment from the council to enhance the Downpatrick area for locals and visitors alike.The Covid recovery grouprsquos proposal is set to be ratied at next monthrsquos meeting of the local authorityrsquos Enterprise, Tourism and Regeneration Committee..prettyPhoto

title: Boundary proposals to have ramifications for voters in Downpatrick
story: SIGNIFICANT changes proposed by the Boundary Commission will dramatically alter the districtrsquos political landscape.While only initial proposals at this stage and subject to public consultation, the ramications of the proposed changes scheduled to come into effect in  mdash which would see the five electoral wards in Downpatrick moved into the Strangford constituency mdash are being viewed by some as huge.The move is part of plans to create a new Strangford and Quoile constituency and would see the transfer of , mostly nationalist votes from Downpatrick.If the proposal is agreed, it would mean that the current Downpatrick wards of Cathedral, Knocknashinna, Lecale, Strangford and Quoile would transfer to the renamed constituency, potentially paving the way for the five wards to have a unionist MP.The current MP for the Downpatrick DEA is Sinn Feinrsquos Chris Hazzard, with the DUPrsquos Jim Shannon the current incumbent in Strangford.Under the proposals unveiled last week, the Boundary Commission is proposing to sht the Ballynahinch and Kilmore wards from Strangford to South Down.In addition, it is being proposed that Saintfield and Moneyreagh would be removed from the Strangford constituency and subsumed into a newly created South Belfast and Mid Down constituency.The rules for the  mean each constituency must have an electorate of between , and ,, reflecting changes in the number of registered voters, and currently  of  current constituencies fall outside this range.South Downrsquos current electorate is ,, while Strangfordrsquos current electorate is  short of , which is too few when compared to national guidelines.Under the proposals, the South Down electorate will be reduced to ,, while the new Strangford and Quoile constituency will have an electorate of ,.As the existing parliamentary constituencies are those established in , but the current local government boundaries are more recent, from , these wards have been used as lsquobuilding blocksrsquo by the Commission in setting out the proposed changes, with the proposals representing the first major change to Northern Ireland constituencies for  years and is part of a review across the UK.Previous proposals to update constituencies in  fell following a legal challenge, although the then plans by Government to cut the number of parliamentary seats from  to , as part of a wider move to reduce MPs at Westminster from  to , were scrapped.The proposals will undergo an eight-week public consultation to allow the public, political parties and wider civic society to share their views on the proposals and further consultations will follow as well as public hearings before a report is submitted to the Speaker in the House of Commons in July .The Boundary Commissionrsquos NI chairman Mr Justice Michael Humphreys is encouraging the public to submit their views, with the organisation keen to encourage everyone with an interest to share their views via the consultation processldquoI am pleased to announce the publication of the commissionrsquos initial proposals and the beginning of the first period of public consultation of the  review, he said.ldquoThe commission is keen to encourage everyone with an interest to share their views by engaging with the consultation process, whether it is to support the proposals, or to suggest alternatives which take into account the requirements of the legislation.Written representations must be received by December  and submitted using the Boundary Commissionrsquos online portal, by email, or by post..prettyPhoto

title: East Down AC runners excel in cross country
story: THE lead up to this event involved a lot of encouraging experienced members to place an entry, persuading new runners to give cross-country a try, getting out spikes from the cupboard and wishing that they had been cleaned at the end of last season ndash plus of course, sage advice on how to tackle the challenging course at Comber.Those who were doing cross country for the first time must have thought they were going into battle with the list of what to bring: EDAC vest, spikes, old trainers to warm up, tape to tie round spikes to keep them on in the muck, bin bags for dirty clothes, a towel and enough kit to last a week.In the end despite the overnight rain, the mud was non-existent and the going was good to firm. It didnrsquot even rain on the day. All in all, it was a good way to start the season.The event included a full programme of junior racing so the atmosphere was buzzing by the time the seniors arrived at the Billy Neill playing fields in Comber.As the last junior race finished, the senior women swarmed to the start area. East Down AC was out in force with  females on the start list plus Wayne Giles by virtue of being in the Male  plus age group was in the same race.The runners were herded into pens to await the whistle and in fact when the race started two minutes early, some of the team were nearly caught on the hop as they were facing the wrong way getting their photo taken.Off they went at a pace across the level grass of the pitches stretching out quickly from a pack to a winding snake of coloured vests.They then turned sharply to get on to the hilliest section for the first time.This part is a gradual but leg sapping climb with the odd flatter bit for respite.Even after reaching the top, there are a few lumpy bits before a welcome downhill section. The runners then have a road crossing to contend with before sweeping round to the next loop.For women and male plus, it was three laps to make the k which meant three chances to try dfering techniques on the hill.At the end of the last lap there was an added cruel twist - a steep uphill to the finish which seemed primarily to be for the entertainment of spectators.It required huge reserves to push to the very end but the cheering onlookers provided the much needed encouragement with gusto.Caroline MacNabb led the team in with a gutsy run. She went out strongly and kept pushing to keep in contention. This earned her eighth overall in . and should encourage her that her consistent training is paying off.Catherine OrsquoConnor not far behind was forced to work hard for her tenth place coming home in  minutes exactly. This placed her first in her age category.Further back the rest of the team were all putting in the hard yards and finished in the following order: Sharon Madine , Wendy Findlay , Maureen Kelly and Janine Murray, who spent the entire race neck and neck, crossed the line together in ., Roisin Gaffney , Alison Carroll , Shauna McGreevyand Rachel Madine .Wayne Giles smiling as always placed nine  veteran men.The women had no time to relax as they took on the supporting role to pay back the shouts given by the EDAC men earlier. The men had an even bigger team.This level of participation is a sign of the numbers currently attending training. The club has definitely bounced back post Covid- and the enthusiasm to race is ing.Neil McCartan was out to show that his recent speedy . for K was no fluke so he was gunning for action.He along with a bunch of sharp shooters came out of the pens at a rate of knots, fighting to get away from the melee and make sure that they were not impeded in any way.Aaron McGrady also close to the front at the start was determined not to get sucked into a chase situation but found it hard to stay controlled when he saw the way the pack was breaking up.Neil ended up having to run solo as the top three were hammering on but to his credit he stayed solid and claimed a worthy fth place finishing in . for K.Aaron settled as per plan and worked his way through the field each lap ending up ninth overall .Gordy Graham wasnrsquot a fan of cross country before and hadnrsquot changed his opinion after but still managed to come th in ..The rest of the team streamed in not far behind.Neil Curran , Conaill MacNabb , Martin Willcox , Jonny Holmes , Barrie Atkinson , Dee Murray , Mark OrsquoConnor , Eamon Holmes , Seamus Savageand John Taylor .Cross country is definitely a dferent kettle of fish from a road race and many found that the iation in terrain made for an interesting outing while others found it an extremely hard session.The truth is that cross country is the most valuable way to pass the winter as it adds strength and stamina and the camaraderie almost makes up for the pain.Hopefully the turnout at Ballyclare in a couple of weeks time will show that that our members have been convinced of the merits.Declan Teague is continuing to push himself by completing multiple marathons in a short time frame.This weekend he headed to Kildare for his third crack at the . miles in five weeks. EDAC was well represented as Phillip Vint, completing his th marathon, and Dermot Cahill were also on the start list for the Thoroughbred Autumn Marathon.They had taken part in this event before but on a two lap route. This time it was one lap which was ldquotough enough according to Declan.He described it as rolling countryside and said that it felt like there was more up than down, with a bit of a headwind for good measure.On a positive note there were many plus points such as welcome sunshine and blue skies, plenty of support along the road, a great t-shirt and medal and best of all chicken curry at the finish.No wonder they recommend this race. All three men were pleased with their run. Declan set himself a target of : and worked hard up to  miles to give himself a cushion for the inevitable slowing after miles.His strategy worked well as he completed in three hours  minutes. Phillip Vint ran a commendable three hours  showing no repercussions from his recent efforts in the London Marathon and Dermot Cahill was pleased to lead the trio home in three hours .They were th, th and st respectively out of the  entries. A great showing on behalf of the club.Sam Anderson headed for Shanersquos Castle for the Championship Half Marathon to make the most of the long miles of training that she has put in for the recent Belfast full marathon.She might also have thought that she was escaping the mud of the cross country as the two events coincided.She was wrong though as overnight rain had left the estate very mucky and their mud was mixed with manure so it was a very smelly, sludgy . miles for Sam.With her usual stoicism, she coped with the adversity and came home smiling in two hours .On Sunday, the junior cross-country season got off with a bang at Billy Neill playing fields in Comber.It was the NI and Ulster Even Age Group Championships and there was a massive entry at all ages. Memories of the horrendous weather the last time it was hosted two years ago were still fresh in everyonersquos minds but it couldnrsquot have been more dferent.The sun shone, the wind was light and the ground was dry even though it had poured the night before.The East Down AC junior entry list was depleted over the days beforehand for a number of reasons but in the end the club had eight runners in five races.The runners were in age categories U-, U-, U-, U- and U- based on their age before the end of December .Luke Napier was first up running in the U- boys racewith his sister Cara running in the U- girls racejust after.Cara was also the clubrsquos only female junior running. This was their first race at this level and although they found the pace tough going they really enjoyed it and were excited to be part of an Ulster race with runners from all parts.Luke came nd out of  runners, the biggest junior field on the day, and Cara came th out of  runners.Alex Robinson, Finn Gibney and Freddie Ferguson were next with ,m in the U- boysrsquo race. As always the start was a mad stampede.As with the Napiers, Alex and Freddie were young in their category and it was Freddiersquos first race of this scale.At the finish Alex said he went off too hard but despite this he managed to come th out of  runners. Finn came th and Freddie st.As the runners get older the distance increases and so it was a tough ,m which faced the U- boys.Jacob Crawford and Oliver Robinson have been training hard over the last few months under the watchful eye of their coaches and race tactics were much discussed before the race.Ollie likes to lead from the front but was given strong advice to sit with the pack. He wasnrsquot surethat helped when he got hemmed in on the first shorter lap of the course in the big leading bunch.Jacob was wisely sat close to Ollie but managed to stay out of trouble. The U- race was the first to include a bigger lap which started with a long uphill section.Thankfully the wind was behind them for part of the lap as it had picked up a bit. This was Jacobrsquos first XC race for EDAC and he did the club proud coming th out of  runners.Ollie was just behind in th place with a sprint finish after struggling with a stitch for over half of the race. Last up for the juniors was MacKenzie Murray in the ,m U- boys race.He stayed resolute with the tough competition and came rd out of  runners. The standard at the age groups is high so all the EDAC Juniors should be proud of how they performed.As well as medals and podiums on the day, runners are seeking qualication for the All-Irelands either as an inidual or via slots based on the placing of their club or county.It is fantastic that as a result of their efforts that Alex Robinson and Finn Gibney , Jacob Crawford and Ollie Robinsonand Mackenzie Murrayhave all qualied to run for the County Down team in Santry Dublin on November .This All-Ireland event will literally take them to another level and is an exciting achievement. Well done boys..prettyPhoto

title: Emily Irish dancing champ
story: FIVE year-old Emily Marner has just become an Irish dancing champion after just two years of dancing.The Crossgar girl won the under- British title last on Saturday at Kensington in London.Emily competed against dancers from all over the UK and Ireland, performing in front of a  of five adjudicators.It was a clean sweep for the local girl as each adjudicator placed her first and she received the maximum possible points of  out of .A pupil of Millennium Integrated Primary School in Carryduff, Emily trains at the Claddagh Academy of Irish Dance based in Carryduff and London.Throughout the pandemic, Emilyrsquos dance classes were on Zoom and helped keep her active and motivated while giving her the opportunity to also catch up with her dance friends in London.Competitions had been put on hold due to the pandemic, however, once restrictions were lted in June, Emily has been competing regularly and won competitions in Dungannon, Enniskillen, Derry and Craigavon..prettyPhoto

title: Ex head gardener shares advice with community group
story: THE former head gardener at the stunningly beautul Rowallane Garden in Saintfield recently shared his wealth of gardening experience with guests at an event organised by the Rowallane and Slieve Croob Community Twinning Group.Throughout his narrated, photographic presentation, Mike Snowdon made reference to his period at Erddig when he restored and recreated the formal th century garden in Wrexham.In addition, Mike made reference to the choice of soil, drainage, planting location for bulbs, shrubs and trees and the choice of plants and trees, relevant to his work at Erddig, which is also applicable for peoplersquos own gardens.In the early seventies, Erddig was on the brink of ruin. In , the last Squire and only remaining heir, Philip Yorke III, handed the house and its contents to the National Trust ready for the biggest conservation challenge faced at that time.In , Mike was appointed head gardener at Erddig, restoring and recreating the formal th century garden.In , he transferred to Rowallane Garden, a natural landscape with a wide-ranging plant collection where he worked as head gardener for  years.In , Mike began a relationship with Ashfield House at Beauparc, Co Meath. Initially, it was for the restoration of the dilapidated walled garden, with the next decade seeing the restoration of the house, outbuildings and the garden, together with the -acre estate.Also during the twinning grouprsquos recent meeting held at the Rowallane Hub in Saintfield, Mrs Sally McCurry, past president of Comber Flower Club, demonstrated beautul autumn flower arrangements, passing on many useful tips to the audience.In addition, she also shared her experience of arranging flowers for the Remembrance Day services in Westminster Abbey in her role of member of the Northern Ireland group of Flower Arrangement Societies.Hazel Bland, Kathleen Lyons and Lawrence Murphy were winners in the auction of the three flower arrangements, with proceeds being donated to the twinning grouprsquos five chosen charities.Guests at the October  meeting were also provided with an overview of Saintfieldrsquos new community garden project by Lawrence Murphy, a member of the Saintfield Community Trust .He shared his ambitious plans to create the garden, a project which he has been working on, inviting Saintfieldrsquos Hen and Menrsquos Shed and the Rowallane Twinning Group to engage in this project.Lawrence said he would soon be launching a cross-community design competition for a community garden which demonstrates the ability of the garden to promote well-being.Thanks were extended to Newry Mourne and Down Council, Letrsquos Grow Newry Mourne and Down and the Police and Community Safety Partnership for the financial assistance which made the recent event possible.At its conclusion, guests were invited to a walk and talk event around Rowallane Gardens led by Mr Snowden..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C October 31%2C 2001
story: DOWNPATRICK mdash THE districtrsquos binmen have warned they could be on strike by ChristmasDown Council does not enter into immediate negotiations about their terms and conduitions of work.Relations between council officials and refuse collectors hit crisis point on Monday evening when workers from the refuse collection and street cleansing sections picketed the local authorityrsquos Strangford Road headquarters.They warned that they would initiate proceedings for industrial actiona solution to their grievances is not soon found.The picket comes just weeks before the expected commencement of an industrial tribunal involving the councilrsquos groundsmen who are also seeking movement on their terms and conditions of work.Council management and binmen have been at odds for almost two years following a dispute over a bonus scheme which was introduced seven years ago under compulsive competitive tendering.Under the scheme, binmen agreed to work overtime and public holidays infor a biannual payment from profits generated by the refuse collection department.But tensions mounted towards the end of the contract when profits within the department dwindled, meaning workers lost out on substantial bonuses. They each received pound at the end of the contract in April but believe they were entitled by much more.The refuse collectors also believe the council is dragging its heels about the introduction of an equal status scheme which will bring the terms and conditions of all council workers into line.CLOUGH mdash Education officials are seeking permission to build a new controlled primary school in Clough.An application to construct the nine classroom building adjacent to the existing Clough Primary was lodged with the Planning Service this week.The building is designed to cater for a new school which will be formed following the merger of Downshire Primary School in Dundrum and the Clough school.The amalgamation was proposed following a review of the primary provision in the greater Newcastle area which revealed dwindling numbers at Downshire and increasing pressure on resources at Clough. A time scale for the merger has not yet been announced by South Eastern Education and Library Board officials.BALLYNAHINCH mdash Pouring pints and pints of alcohol down the drain may sound like a waste to some, but for police in Ballynahinch last week it was a very successful operation.On Friday officers and one of Down Councilrsquos enforcement officers poured out drink from dozens of bottles and cans which had been seized from local teenagers over the summer months.In the joint initiative police and the council started seizing alcohol from teenagers who were drinking in and around Ballynahinch town centre.The aim of the scheme, which has already been carried out in other parts of the district, was to cut down on the amount of underage drinking and reducing what police described as antisocial behaviour.Over the summer, community beat officers and the councilrsquos enforcement officer, Mr Graham Lever, carried out numerous joint foot patrols dealing with underage drinking, drinking in public and littering.NEWCASTLE mdash A police inspector has warned that the lack of facilities for teenagers in Newcastle may be contributing to crime in the town.Inspector Stephen Reid told a meeting of the new pressure group, Newcastle Community Safety Focus, that levels of underage drinking in the town were high and he didnrsquot think there were ldquosufficient facilities for children and teenagers.Over  local residents attended the grouprsquos first annual meeting to hear Inspector Reid warn that there was a link between teenagers drinking and a certain amount of crime in the town.The recently established group, which has vowed to devote its time and efforts to the needs of the people who live and work in the resort, was expected to address the problem at a special meeting of its Youth Taskforce yesterday.Inspector Reid said the levels of underage drinking in the town were ldquohigh and conceded that he didnrsquot think there were adequate facilities or resources for children and teenagers in Newcastle.COMBER mdash A high-tech method is to be used to keep track of some of naturersquos highflyers who arrived in Strangford Lough recently.The Wildfowl and Wetlands Trust at Castle Espie is to fit sophisticated tracking devices to Brent geese which will spend the winter at the Comber centre.Strangford Lough is currently home to , light-bellied Brent geese, the largest flock ever, which made a , mile journey from the eastern Canadian Arctic.When the birds make their epicjourney next spring, six will be pioneering the very latest telemetry technology in the cause of conservation ndash helping to safeguard their own future and the long-term conservation of the gregarious goose.The birds will be fitted with satellite transmitters that will enable conservation scientists based at the Wildfowl and Wetlands Trustrsquos headquarters in Slimbridge to track their progress mile by mile.BALLYHORNAN mdash Plans for a pound, scheme to upgrade sewage facilities in Ballyhornan have been outlined by local Water Service officials.Local politicians were told on Monday night that the scheme is currently at the appraisal stage, with work expected to start within the next two years.Confirmation that the scheme has been included in the WaterServicersquos capital works programme comes exactly a year after residents revealed sewage from over  homes in the area was being pumped into the sea off Ballyhornan.The residents, who live at the former RAF base at Bishopscourt, also claimed they were being forced to endure a World War  sewerage system and pointed to the need for the network of sewers in the area to be upgraded.News of the improvement work has been welcomed by councillor Peter Craig who said the problems in the Ballyhornan area have been well chronicled over the past number of years.KILCLIEF mdash The culmination of the centenary celebrations at Kilclief Ben Dearg GAC takes place next month.Joe McDonagh, the former president of the GAA, will be the guest of honour at a centenary gala dinner in the Sieve Donard Hotel, Newcastle, on Friday, November .Players, past and present, and members and supporters spanning several generations will gather for what promises to be a night to remember at the end of what has already been a memorable year.Kilclief Ben Dearg is pressing ahead with an impressive development scheme, a history of the club is about to be published and the senior team ended the season by retaining its Division  status in the county league.On the playing front, Kilclief may be a long way from days when its hurlers ruled the county or, in the not so distant past, when the footballers won the senior county league in the early s.The development of modern facilities at the picturesque St Malachyrsquos Park ground is an important step as the club enters its second century.KILLOUGH mdash A business which farms oysters freshly from the shores of Killough Bay is continuing to go from strength to strength.Certain that Lecale Shellfish has a promising future, Down Councilrsquos Cultural and Economic Development committee has agreed to grant pound, to the company, which was recently allocated an EC Health Mark permitting the sale of its oysters direct to the public..prettyPhoto

title: Joe Duffy shares his life and faith views
story: RTE presenter and author Joe Duffy says he is unsurethere is an afterle butthere is, he would like to do some good in Heaven.The broadcaster was sharing his le story and his views on faith in Downpatrick last Thursday evening as part of an autumn lecture series at the Saint Patrick Centre.Duffy, who hosts the radio talkshow Liveline and presents the television series The Meaning of Le, spoke to veteran broadcaster Gerry Kelly.In a wide-ranging interview in front of a -strong audience in the centrersquos theatre, he shared his own views on faith and le.ldquoMy family are more anti-church than I am, said Duffy, who stressed there are still ldquogood people in the church.He revealed that he sometimes gets moments of serenity from looking at stained glass windows in basilicas or from art galleries and museums, adding: ldquoI get serenity from reading and walking. I donrsquot watch much television.Askedhe believed in the afterle, he said: ldquoI donrsquot know butI thought I was on my way out I would start studying for my finals.On a serious note, he continued: ldquoI want to be a do-gooder. I canrsquot work outwe invented God or God invented us. But I would rather be a do-gooder than a do-badder. There is no greater sensation in le than being a giver.Turning to the audience, he said: ldquoBe a giver. Be a giver.Asked what he would sayhe arrived at the pearly gates, he said that he might askthere was radio before offering to do some good in Heaven. ldquoMaybe chastise Ian Paisley.Duffy recalled that he met the late DUP leader  years ago when he was working on a documentary on St Patrick. He said Dr Paisley had talked of his support for making St Patrickrsquos Day a national holiday and boasted that St Patrick once lived in his North Antrim constituency.While Duffy has suffered personal tragedy, including the death of his younger brother, Aidan, aged  in a traffic accident, he said he was very blessed in his le. ldquoI have no money worries and thank God my children are healthy.The married father of three grown-up triplets describes himself as a Christian socialist. He signed copies of his latest book, Children of the Troubles, co-authored with journalist Freya McClements.He said it was important to tell the stories of children who were killed in the Troubles as they would not have direct descendants, children and grandchildren to ensure they were remembered.ldquoNobody deserved to die and everyone deserves to be remembered.Dr Tim Campbell, director of the Saint Patrick Centre, thanked the two award-winning broadcasters for sharing their talents in the community of Downpatrick.ldquoWe had intended to have Joe Duffy here two years ago, but the series was interrupted due to Covid, he said.ldquoIt has certainly been worth the wait and it was great to see people gathered again for a wonderfully informative and entertaining evening.Gerry Kelly said it was a ldquoprivilege to hear about Joe Duffyrsquos journey, which took him from Dublin tenements to Trinity College to one of the top posts in Irish broadcasting..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle RNLI looking for volunteer press officer
story: NEWCASTLE RNLI is looking for a new volunteer leboat press officer to join its station team and help raise local awareness of the charity that saves lives at sea.The press officer will promote the operational activity of the station and share information on newsworthy rescues to highlight the lesaving work of the all-weather and inshore leboat crews, while also delivering important water safety and fundraising messages.The rescue service is seeking someone who can write and distribute regular new releases, handle media requests, support media opportunities and facilitate press interviews.The role is best suited to someone with good writing and communication skills, who lives within a good distance of the station and can be flexible with their time.Newcastle RNLIrsquos Leboat operations manager Lisa Ramsden said volunteers are at the heart of the organisation and make up  per cent of its people.ldquoThey are ordinary people who do extraordinary things and without them we couldnrsquot save lives at sea, she said. ldquoVolunteering with the RNLI gives people the opportunity to make a real dference in the local community, to save lives and become part of the larger RNLI family.Lisa explained that becoming a volunteer was a great chance for someone to play a crucial part in helping to save lives at sea.ldquoWe are looking for an enthusiastic person with good writing and interpersonal skills and who enjoys working with people and at times under pressure to inform the media and update our community on the ious lesaving activities that are happening at the station from rescues to fundraising, community safety to events, she added.Anyone interested in the press officer role is asked to visit https:volunteering.rnli.org vacancy volunteer-leboat-press-officer-.html to find out more and apply.The closing date for applications is October ..prettyPhoto

title: Opening of community centre in Ballykinlar
story: BALLYKINLARrsquoS new community centre has been officially opened.The Commons Road building is located at the site of the villagersquos former Kindle Primary School and will be a major asset for local people and community groups.The new centre, which was previously used to house former Down Council building control staff at the Strangford Road in Downpatrick, was relocated to Ballykinlar with community representatives delighted that is is now open for use.Newry, Mourne and Down Council chairwoman Cathy Mason officially opened the new building and was joined by local authority officials, councillors and community representatives.Members of the Ballykinlar and Tyrella Community Association, who worked with Slieve Croob councillors and the local authority to bring the facility to le, say they are delighted that the centre is now available for use.The local authority purchased the former primary school for the project and installed a prefabricated building, which consists of a large recreational space, smaller meeting room and kitchen and toilet facilities.Officials say that the new centre will allow a wide range of community services to be delivered in the Ballykinlar, Tyrella and surrounding area and, most importantly, contribute to improvements in health and well-being in the area.Ballykinlar and Tyrella Community Association chairman, Mr Nial Addis, said there was a long-term commitment involved in bringing the project to fruition and paid tribute to the grouprsquos volunteers who were the driving force for the development of the new centre.He added ldquoThis is the beginning of a new era for the community of Ballykinlar and Tyrella. We now have excellent facilities on our doorstep that will be of benefit to all.Cllr Mason said the development of the new centre will create new opportunities for the people of Ballykinlar, Tyrella and surrounding areas.She continued: ldquoOne of the councilrsquos key aims is to provide high quality community facilities and to explore partnership opportunities to ensure sustainability of community services.ldquoIt also aims to build community capacity to empower local people to effect change within their communities, and this beautul building is an excellent example of partnership working between statutory and voluntary groups.Downpatrick area councillor, Dermot Curran, who played a key role to persuade the council to move its former building control headquarters in Downpatrick to Ballykinlar to provide the new centre, is delighted that it has been officially open.ldquoThe centre is located in an ideal site at the Commons Road and will be a major asset for the people in the village. The new centre has taken a long time to deliver and the perseverance and determination of local people and the Ballykinlar and Tyrella Community Association has paid off, he said.ldquoI am particularly pleased for Mr Addis who invested so much time and energy in this particular project. His hard work and that of others has been rewarded and he deserves thanks.Cllr Curran said he has no doubt that the community centre will be a very widely used facility and will be able to accommodate the needs of a wide range of users..prettyPhoto

title: Siobhan McCann charity fund equips chemo unit
story: MONEY from a charity fund set in the name of much loved Clanaghan woman Siobhan McCann donated to the South Eastern Trust helped equip a redesigned chemotherapy unit at the Ulster Hospital.Siobhan mdash who was a noted Gaelic footballer mdash sadly lost her battle with cancer in May , with her parents Brendan and Geraldine donating pound, to the South Eastern Trust for the redesigned Macmillan Unit at the Dundonald hospital which was officially opened recently.Her family and friends raised a staggering pound, which was distributed to cancer charities and health professionals helping people, children and young people live as well as possible with the disease.The fund was initially launched to pay for immunotherapy treatment for Siobhan, an appeal which sparked a huge community response and support from GAA clubs across Ireland.Siobhan, a former senior ladies player with St Johnrsquos GAC, Drumnaquoile and the Dulwich Harps in London, where she previously lived and worked, was diagnosed with colorectal cancer  months before she sadly lost her le.The South Eastern Trust and Macmillan Cancer Support have thanked the McCann family for the signicant donation from their daughterrsquos fund to the Macmillan Chemotherapy Redesign Programme Board.Before Siobhan passed away, she told her family and her best friend Cormac McMullan how she wanted the money that had been raised for her fund to be spent.The pound, from the fund supported the redesign and development of the new chemotherapy unit in partnership with Macmillan Cancer Support at the Ulster Hospital.The donation funded  state-of-the-art chemotherapy chairs with in built tables and lights,  ergonomically designed chemo stools for the nurses,  privacy screens and two computers on wheels.Siobhanrsquos parents Brendan and Geraldine, her brother Ciaran and best friend Cormac had a personal tour of the new unit late last month before it opened.They received a token of appreciation on behalf of the chemotherapy redesign programme board from Mary Jo Thompson, interim assistant director medicine and cancer, Paula Kealey, and Laura Scott, Macmillan Unit ward manager.The gt was a picture of the primrose which is taken from the Latin word for Siobhan which means grace. One of the flowers which represent grace is the primrose.The health trustrsquos interim director said the huge donation from Siobhanrsquos fund helped secure state-of-the-art equipment for the unit to enhance the patientsrsquo comfort.ldquoThe chemotherapy chairs are very comfortable and have been really well received by all the patients, she continued.ldquoIt is a fitting legacy for Siobhan to leave and the Trust and Macmillan are very appreciative that Siobhan specically chose the chemo unit at the Ulster Hospital for this donation.Joanne Young, from the Northern Ireland Macmillan Fundraising Team, said the charity is ldquoincredibly grateful to Siobhan and her family for their generous donation to the Macmillan Unit.She added: ldquoThese chemotherapy chairs will make a huge dference to the comfort and well-being of people receiving treatment and care.The other groups Siobhanrsquos fund supported included the Cancer Fund for Children, which runs the Daisy Lodge Centre in Newcastle, the Friends of the Cancer Centre based at Belfast City Hospital, the Northern Ireland Hospice, Castlewellan and Newcastle District Nurses, The Little Princess Trust and Donard Family Practice..prettyPhoto

title: Television production on Strangford Lough
story: A NEWS series about Strangford Lough, its people and its habitat comes to UTV tomorrow evening.lsquoKeepers of the Loughrsquo is a six-part series which will take the viewer on a beautul journey of discovery.Renowned internationally for its sheer beauty with its marine and nature reserves, Strangford Lough is also a working lough and its shores are surrounded by people who not only look after and keep it, but also depend on it for a living.Narrated by Patrick Kielty, the series will reveal whatrsquos le is like in and around the lough. Along the way, wersquoll meet great characters, encounter the highs and lows of not only having to depend on the Northern Ireland weather, but also on the actions of others to survive, and indeed thrive, in this area of outstanding natural beauty.In the first episode, we meet Hugh Thurgate, the National Trustrsquos Lead Ranger on Strangford Lough, who talks about the work of the Trust as he helps to move cattle for a tenant with the Trustrsquos barge. Itrsquos not all plain sailing though with wayward cattle in the wrong place on one of the islands.John Scott, from Killyleagh, has been working at Ringhaddy Boatyard since the early s when he helped his father, Bobby, as a teenager. Hersquos an expert in the yard, painstakingly manoeuvring a yacht for launch, with inches to spare, and waiting for the tide to take her out.Cadogan Enright, from Downpatrick, and members of his canoe club, are carrying out a week-long butterfly survey on all the islands on the Lough. Spending just  minutes on each island, and covering over km, they count the species, and in doing so contribute to the UK-wide Big Butterfly Count.At Exploris Aquarium we meet Cloddagh McVeigh, a local girl from Kircubbin who started there while on work experience at school. She has been working with rescue seals for two years and we see her give one abandoned seal a thorough health check, with lots of cuddles of course.We also meet boat builder Dan Dorman, on his tall ship at Whiterock. He grew up on Strangford Lough and he shares his renovation dreams and plans to sell his house to finish the work so he and his family can live onboard.And there is stunning footage of Dan at sunrise moving his tall ship on to a mooring around the other side of Sketrick Island.Wilmer McFerran from Killyleagh is a ldquogenius, according to John Scott. Wilmer tinkers at boats and diggers in his old shed, and can turn his hand to fixing anything. We find out at the end of the programmehe has success with an old rope-making machine.Further in the series, viewers will get to see the work at Castle Espie and at the RNLI station at Portaferry, as well as meet more local people who use the lough for work and play.UTVrsquos Programmes Editor, Tony Curry, said, ldquoStrangford is an area of outstanding natural beauty and that, coupled with the great characters the viewers will meet and get to know across the six episodes, add up to a truly special series that the viewers will love.Bob OrsquoBrien from Independent production company Green Inc has produced, shot and directed the series for UTV.Green Inc, owner Stephen Stewart said: ldquoWe are delighted to bring the beauty of Strangford into homes in Northern Ireland. This is a real passion project for us, as both my family and Bobrsquos family are connected to people who live and work there.ldquoIt is an amazing place and whether they are scientists, conservationists, farmers or boatman, everyone loves it and they all make up a very special community interlocked and dependent on one another, living where the sea and land merge.You can watch the first episode tomorrow at .pm on UTV and on catch up on www.itv utvprogrammes..prettyPhoto

title: Time ticking on work to repair Shrigley clock
story: FRESH appeals have been issued for the restoration of the historic Shrigley clock, with Stormont communities minister Deirdre Hargey urged to step in to help put the tick back in the ageing structure.Owned by the Housing Executive, the Martin Memorial clock dates back to the Victorian era, with ious calls made over many decades for it to be restored to its former glory.The latest politicians to throw their weight behind the campaign are Strangford MLAs Michelle McIlveen and Harry Harvey who, in addition to raising the issue with Ms Hargey, have contacted Housing Executive chief executive Grainia Long.The housing body is responsible for the clock which had its bell and interior mechanism removed over three decades ago and placed in storage.Many are concerned to see the historic landmark falling into disrepair, but hopeful that it can be restored to be enjoyed for generations to come to reinforce its connection with the villagersquos industrial past.Shrigley was founded by the Martin family, who came from Pott Shrigley in Cheshire in  and who owned the spinning factory in the village.It was powered by water supplied from the nearby Clea Lough and while the mill mdash which is reported to have employed  people at one time mdash has long gone, the clock tower erected by the people of Shrigley in  in honour of the Martin family remains.Ms McIlveen mdash who is also the current Stormont education minister mdash said the clock which enjoys protected status and is one of the last remaining pieces of Victorian architecture in the village.She said while full restoration could be very expensive, there is a need to focus on what can be done in the interim to prevent further deterioration of the clock.ldquoIt is unacceptable that an old clock of this signicance and splendour should be allowed to fall into such a sad state of repair, she declared.Ms McIlveen said that previously, funding was provided for a conservation management plan by the Department for Communities Historic Environment Division which was developed on behalf of the Follies Trust.She said the report found that it would cost almost pound, to fully restore the Shrigley clock tower, a cost which the Housing Executive was unwilling to meet.Ms McIlveen and Mr Harvey said they have written to the housing body to not only highlight its public responsibility to maintain this listed property in its possession, but stressed the importance of the monument to the people of Shrigley:ldquoMonuments such as these are an important snapshot of our history and part of the fabric of our built heritage which should be cherished and protected said Ms McIlveen.ldquoWe have asked chief executive Grainia Long to outline what measures can be put in place ahead of a full restoration of the clock.The MLAs added: ldquoWhile I appreciate that full renovation works might be extremely expensive, it is very important that further deterioration of the monument does not occur.In a response to the Strangford Assembly members, Ms Long confirmed the clock is owned by the Housing Executive and sits on land transferred to it in the early s by the local council.She continued: ldquoThe condition of the monument has been raised with us and other agencies on a number of occasions and I can assure you that I appreciate the interest in our plans for it. ldquoHowever, while we have recently undertaken minor works to de-weed the monument and address any potential health and safety issues, it is our position that, at a time at which we have a signicant funding shortfall for investment in our tenantsrsquo homes, it would not be appropriate to use income derived from rents to fund the considerable costs that would be required to undertake a full restoration.The Housing Executive chief executive said that over the years, the organisation has explored options with others to secure the restoration and long-term sustainability of the monument but that these had proved unsuccessful.However, Ms Long said the Executive remains open to speaking to any interested parties and looking at any proposals.She added: ldquoThe establishment of a trust or the monumentrsquos disposal to, for example, a heritage organisation appear to be the best long-term courses of action and we would be happy to discuss these again with Newry, Mourne and Council and others..prettyPhoto

title: Vandals target special school
story: A SPECIAL school in Castlewellan which caters for young adults with learning dficulties is being targeted by vandals and others dabbling in drugs.Politicians have united in their condemnation of ongoing trouble at Knockevin Senior School which recently opened at the site of the former Castlewellan Primary at Mill Hill.Following one recent incident, staff were forced to close the school.Attempts have been made to strip lead from the roof of the building and, more worryingly, drug paraphernalia has been found in the school grounds and in the vicinity of St Paulrsquos Church of Ireland church which is next door.Underage drinking in the school grounds has also been reported, while electrics and a satellite dish have also been damaged, with staff concerned about the risk the ongoing trouble poses to vulnerable students.Police have been asked to increase patrols and it has been confirmed that additional security measures are to be implemented, with politicians hoping that there are no further incidents during the Halloween holiday.The elected representatives, who have been liaising with Education Authority outreach workers and the anti-social behaviour committee attached to the districtrsquos Policing and Community Safety Partnership , have called for the Castlewellan trouble to end.They have warned that Halloween must not be used by troublemakers as an opportunity to step up their anti-social behaviour, appealing to those involved in recent incidents to show more respect to education and church properties.Slieve Croob councillors Alan Lewis, Roiacutesiacuten Howell and Cathy Mason mdash who have appealed to anyone who knows those involved in anti-social behaviour to contact police mdash say the trouble must stop.Cllr Lewis, the current PCSP chairman, has appealed to young people to stay away from Knockevin school and the nearby church. He said teenagers who are not a ldquopositive part of the Castlewellan community should remain at home.He visited the school last week where a Halloween party was in full swing and revealed he was disappointed to learn of further incidents of anti-social behaviour.ldquoOnce again, youths had entered the school grounds, climbed on the roof and attempted to remove led, with drug paraphernalia and empty medication packets also found, confirmed Cllr Lewis.ldquoMembers of St Paulrsquos Church leaving a service found empty pill boxes littering the area outside. The fact that a service was taking place did not put these people off and the mentality and lack of respect which is being shown is shocking beyond reason.Cllr Lewis said empty packets of Pregabalin are routinely found at the school and church and warned those who consume them are potentially at risk from blackouts or death.He added: ldquoThere is a fear that over Halloween that the anti-social behaviour will intensy and we hope that does not happen. I will be working with local council staff, police, youth workers and colleagues to ensure the Halloween period is quiet and appeal for a no-nonsense approach to this issue.Cllr Howell she and Cllr Mason recently visited the new school to welcome staff, pupils and parents to the Castlewellan community.ldquoI was deeply disappointed when contacted by the school last week to learn about the anti-social behaviour taking place in the grounds. In one incident, vandalism caused to the property led to the closure of the building, she confirmed.ldquoI am disappointed and frustrated that a small number of youths are causing these issues to a special school. I know first-hand the work and commitment that is put in to delivering the curriculum to the Knockevin children.Confirming that she and her colleague have raised these issues with the PSNI and asked for increased patrols in the vicinity of the school, Cllr Howell said she has also been liaising with Education Authority outreach workers and the PCSP to ensure everything possible is being done to alleviate the ongoing trouble.ldquoNo school should have to face these issues and I would ask for the wider community to be vigilant and report any activity of this nature to police as soon as they become aware of it, she added.Describing the Castlewellan trouble as ldquocompletely unacceptable, Cllr Mason said it will not be tolerated by the community in Castlewellan which is a safe and pleasant place to live.She added: ldquoThe management of the school have reported incidents such as underage drinking, damage to electrics and a satellite dish and roof tiles being broken, along with drug paraphernalia being left on the ground and a multitude of rubbish.ldquoStaff are understandably concerned about the potential risk to pupilsthey were to find any of these items, as well as the potential risk to the youths themselves on top of a school building..prettyPhoto

title: Victory for ‘Hinch men
story: THIS Intermediate League game started at a fast pace, with both teams wanting to retain possession.Although CI got the ball into the Hinch , the home side showed some great defending and quickly cleared the danger.Hinch continued to display some skilful hockey passing the ball around the back from Andrew Mulholland, Ray Coffey to either Ashley Brown or Craig Harkness on the wings.This enabled Hinch to tactically move the ball up the pitch, allowing Matthew Martin to have a shot on goal.Unfortunately, it went wide hitting the side of the goal while, at the other end, Aaron Donnell was on form in nets, saving any balls getting through the strong defence.During play, Coffey was able to find the back of the net, unfortunately he was just slightly outside the CI circle.The second quarter began with the Hinch men in defensive mode and able to keep the ball out of the net.As time progressed, they settled into the game and pushing the ball up the pitch towards Martin and Adam Dodds while there was some great passing across the back from Mulholland to Harkness across to Brown.The latter was able to work the ball up the pitch, passing to Jason Campbell who saw the opportunity to knit the ball across the CI goal, to be tapped in by the prolic Alex Millar.Quarter three began with Hinch gaining the first of several penalty corners, although were unable to break though the CI defence. aEnd to end play continued with each team determined to score. Josh Higginson fought past CI players to get the ball up to Scott Leech, passing across to Campbell who saw his shot saved by the CI keeper.Coffey threw a long aerial ball brought down cleanly by Adam Dodds who fired it across to Michael Carney. Although the ball was intercepted by CI, it was quickly won back by Andrew McIlwaine who saw his chance and, after a one-on-one with the lsquokeeper, scored Hinchrsquos second goal of the match.The home side continued to move up the pitch with many balls ending up over the CI baseline.Quarter four began with both teams wanting to increase their scores, with the end-to-end play continuing with Carney gaining a chance on goal.Unfortunately, the ball deflected off the post. With the use of the rolling substitutes, Hinch were able to keep the high pace game moving.CI continued to push up and after breaking down the Hinch defence, scored their only goal goal of the match.A series of green cards dotted through the play although neither team was able to use this to their advantage.From a penalty corner Mulholland gained possession, moving the ball swtly up the pitch to Coffey who set up up Brown to cross for Millar to make it -Both teams fought to try and score right up to the final whistle but it was the Ballynahinch outfit who ran out victorious..prettyPhoto

It was a damp quib. The organisers appear to have been more concerned to avoid offending nationalists than to offer anything positiveHow refreshing it was to read Ben Lowry’s critique of the centenary service in Armagh and the wider programme of events — a rare articulation of a unionist perspective on the subject Northern Ireland, ’ October , see link below. What a damp squib the centenary has been as the organisers appear to have been more concerned to avoid offending nationalists than to offer anything bold or positive. Of course it was never going to be possible to avoid offending nationalism, which likes nothing better than an opportunity to wallow in historical grievances and has seized on the centenary as an opportunity to tell us all about the ‘great wrong’ of ‘partition’ and how it is the source of all our problems. Please try again later.Submitting...Letter to the editorThis response was predictable but the unionist approach to the centenary has been a pathetic concession to the nationalist narrative. Does unionism today really lack the confidence publicly to defend, never mind celebrate Northern Ireland and to challenge the nationalist view  Why hasn’t the centenary been used to remind people that ‘partition’ was not an imposition on nationalists by unionists, but a compromise between nationalism and unionism  One hundred years ago there were two equally valid and equally determined assertions of self-determination: granting independence to nationalist-majority Ireland and allowing unionist-majority Ireland to remain in the UK was the obvious and most reasonable solution that satisfied a majority of both peoples.The nationalists’ ‘solution’ was for their self-determination entirely to override that of unionists: a victory rather than a compromise. That would have been the great wrong. Where is the unionist articulation of this narrative  Where is the appreciation that Northern Ireland facilitated generations of British people on this island to remain as citizens of the United Kingdom, and to continue to play a role and contribute to the le of the UK, not least in our contribution to the war against Nazism  Where is the reminder that — until the s— people in Northern Ireland enjoyed higher living standards than those in the Republic, greater access to secondary and tertiary education, better public services, and were spared the oppressive censorship and social conservatism of the South  Where is the celebration of the successful determination of a proud people to retain their membership of the UK and withstand the attempt to coerce them into another state against their clear will  J. I saw a large, black silhouette near the desk of what I had the impression was a man,” Ken tells the podcast.“The first thing that struck me, because I was analysing this data as much as possible, was that I’d never seen anything so black. It was just the blackest black I’d ever seen.“At exactly the same moment two things happened. One was I could hear in my ears what I could only describe as very, very loud white noise and also there was a very, very strong sense of pure distilled evil coming from this figure.”“It felt like a force of nature, everything that is good, everything that is called hope had disappeared, so there’s just complete and utter dispair.”Ken went on to give other examples of unexplained phenomenon during his time on the sixth floor of Alanbrooke Hall, which is now demolished.Presenter Danny Robins gave an interview to BBC Radio Ulster following the success of the first episode of his podcast.He said: “It’s an index of how strange he finds this experience that he wanted to talk about it and for Ken, he wants answers, he wants people to come forward,people lived in Room  did they have similar experiences “Already, since this went out last week, we’ve had people coming forward with other experiences.”• BBC Radio ’s Uncanny is available on BBC Sounds with new episodes added weekly.——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: rachel riley how to navigate your way through equations and fractions
story: Trial scheme in which councils will give people free money takes step closer   Bryson: DUP will collapse Stormont on two conditionsNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsPeopleRACHEL RILEY: ‘How to navigate your way through equations and fractions’Countdown maths whizz Rachel Riley talks to Hannah Stephenson about motherhood, marriage to her ex-Strictly partner Pasha Kovalev and her new book on demystying alegbra for confused adultsBy The NewsroomFriday, th October , : pm  "       "  Countdown star Rachel Riley has written a new book aimed at demystying mathematics for confused adultsMake-up free and dressed down in a black T-shirt and leggings, the Countdown maths geek is now on maternity leave, leaving the Countdown team of Susie Dent and new anchor Anne Robinson to run the ship in her absence.Robinson, known for her acerbic putdowns on Weakest Link, joined the long-running afternoon show in June, replacing Nick Hewer. What’s it been like working with her “It’s completely dferent,” says Riley. “We used to all be in the same room together but because of coronavirus everyone’s off separately having their make-up done so we don’t see each other as much. We’ve not really done much team bonding.   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...Rachel with her now husband Pasha Kovalev during rehearsals for Strictly Come Dancing in “Obviously, we had  years with Nickand we really knew each other. Sheis a completely dferent character.”For now, the -year-old maths whizz is understandably much more focused on motherhood. Her Russian husband Pasha Kovalev, erstwhile dance partner from Strictly in , has been fantastic with their toddler daughter, Maven, who turns two in December.“He’s the best dad in the world,” Riley beams. “He’s amazingly patient and will let me sleep in in the morning and look after her when I’ve been up working late.“He’s taken to being a dad like a duck to water. And Maven looks just like him. He goes to the soft play, the bouncy castle and the park – then I get home and he’s made dinner!”Rachel Riley has decided to remind us all how to ide and conquer once more, mostly by mastering long ision, fractions and alegbraThe presenter started dating Kovalev after orcing her husband, Jamie Gilbert, who was a fellow Oxford University student, in .Today, she is clearly still besotted with her professional dancer other half. “He’s the most unique person I’ve ever met. He’s such a chilled, calming influence. Nothing fazes him.”She’s planning to have her second baby at homeand isn’t intending on going on a massive drive toto her pre-pregnancy weight quickly.“I’ll be breastfeeding, so you need the calories. If you are losing it really quickly it just means you are probably not giving your baby what it needs. The weight comes off in its own time and I’ve got a whole range of dresses ready in dferent sizes for when I go back to work.”She’s still breastfeeding Maven, although she hopes that will subside in the New Year, and hopes to be back at work in January, she says.“When you have a newborn, and especially when you have a toddler as well, you don’t have time for a shower. So when I get back to work someone will be paid to do my hair and make-up. You don’t recognise yourself the first time you go back because you’ve just been in mum mode and haven’t washed your hair for a while.”She and her family live in London and also have an apartment in Manchester, where Countdown is filmed. Kovalev will look after the children while Riley is working on the show, taking the baby in for breastfeeding when she’s on a break.They don’t want any more children after the new baby, she says.“We only want two. You can fit two in the car, that kind of stuff. It was a maths decision,” she says, laughing.They married in Las Vegas in  when she was pregnant with Maven, she recalls.“My friend was taking a sabbatical in the States. She said she was going to Vegas and askedI wanted to come to see Robbie Williams. We said, great. Then, when I was four months pregnant, just before the trip, Pasha said, ‘Shall we get married next week ’ We found a little chapel and I bought my dress the day before the wedding.”This year Riley has written At Sixes And Sevens, a maths book for adults, featuring tips and tricks on how to navigate your way through the minefield of equations, formulas, fractions, algebra and BODMAS , among other conundrums.“I’ve always enjoyed making maths accessible and trying to demysty it, even when I was at school,” she says.Her acumen is clearly rubbing off. “My daughter has already started counting on her hands, one, two, three,” she enthuses. “And she can do it in Russian as well.”Riley, who grew up in Essex, studied maths at Oxford University and clinched the Countdown job pretty soon afterwards. As a top maths scholar, did she ever feel her brain could be better utilised than it is on a popular show “I enjoy what I do,” she says simply. “Being on TV has afforded me lots of opportunities and I’m lucky I get to use my maths background as an advocate for maths and science and numeracy.“Through programmes like It’s Not Rocket Science I get to meet people who want to break the land speed record with the fastest car in the world, I got to interview Tim Peake. I’ve got the background to give me enough confidence to interview these people.”For now though, she is having to take things a bit easier. While knowing that sleep deprivation is coming with the new arrival, she is trying to enjoy her Friday night treat – episodes of Ted Lasso, supporting Manchester Utd , going to the park and meeting friends and family.Riley and Kovalev don’t watch Strictly these days, but do keep in touch with some of her old Strictly cohorts, Sophie Ellis-Bextor and Deborah Meaden, and a while ago they went to Majorca to see Brendan Cole and his family.And though she might feel tired right now, Riley is also planning an energetic future for when she is ready: “Once I’m back on my feet, I’ll be ready for a new challenge,” she says.Thanks to Rachel you can master long ision and fractions once moreOn Countdown, Rachel famously replaced the long-serving fellow maths wizard Carol Vorderman. Like Vorderman, Riley’s role is to handle the placement of tiles on the board for the letters and numbers rounds and to find an exact solution in the numbers roundsthe contestants are unable to do so.Riley’s appointment to Countdown was announced at the same time as new main host Jeff Stelling replaced Des O’Connor the duo of Stelling and Riley was in place for the new series beginning in January .Although she had never had any ambition to become a television presenter, Rachel was encouraged to apply for the show by her mother, and decided to do so because she was interested in the numbers part of the game. Having beaten , applicants for the role, she said: “There’s only one cool maths job around and I was lucky enough to get it so I’m absolutely thrilled”.Since it was first broadcast on January , , Riley has also performed her Countdown role on the comedy crossover spin-off version,  Out of  Cats Does Countdown, alongside comedian and host Jimmy Carr, team masters Susie Dent and Jon Richardson and a revolving door of guest stars including Bob Mortimer, David Mitchell, Richard Aoyade and other comedy greats of our time. While Countdown is seen as a straight light entertainment show, in explaining the dference between the two, Riley sees Countdown as the role she is “happy for her grandmother to see”, while Cats Does Countdown is the more risqué, cheeky role which she shows to her friends.Her new book, At Sixes and Sevens, is described as “an engaging, accessible introduction into how numbers work and why we shouldn’t be afraid of them.”It’s designed for those of us who don’t know our fractions from our percentages, or what is adjacent to the hypotenuse on a triangle or exactly how to help your offspring with long ision since those brain cells very likely perished long ago.According to the blurb: “You won’t be At Sixes and Sevens for long. In this brilliant, well-rounded guide, Rachel Riley will take you back to the very basics, allow you to revisit what you learnt at school , build your understanding of maths from the get-go and provide you with the essential toolkit to gain confidence in your numerical abilities.”Sounds like a tome the less numerically literate could definitely benefit from reading -though flashbacks from the agony of double maths at school may ensue.At Sixes And Sevens by Rachel Riley is published by HarperCollins, priced £..Maven  "       "  Get the latest news on the CoronavirusWe have launched a title: thought week journey life
